qTextArr: ['I am waiting,', 'Do come in. The light is quite perfect, and\nyou can bring your drinks.']
qText:
I am waiting, Do come in. The light is quite perfect, and
you can bring your drinks.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['You are glad you have met me, Mr. Gray,']
qText: You are glad you have met me, Mr. Gray,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, I am glad now. I wonder shall I always be glad?']
qText: Yes, I am glad now. I wonder shall I always be glad?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Always! That is a dreadful word. It makes me shudder when I hear it.
Women are so fond of using it. They spoil every romance by trying to
make it last for ever. It is a meaningless word, too. The only
difference between a caprice and a lifelong passion is that the caprice
lasts a little longer.']
qText:
Always! That is a dreadful word. It makes me shudder when I hear it.
Women are so fond of using it. They spoil every romance by trying to
make it last for ever. It is a meaningless word, too. The only
difference between a caprice and a lifelong passion is that the caprice
lasts a little longer.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['In that case, let our friendship be a caprice,']
qText: In that case, let our friendship be a caprice,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It is quite\nfinished,']
qText:
It is quite
finished,
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['My dear fellow, I congratulate you most warmly,', 'It is the\nfinest portrait of modern times. Mr. Gray, come over and look at\nyourself.']
qText:
My dear fellow, I congratulate you most warmly, It is the
finest portrait of modern times. Mr. Gray, come over and look at
yourself.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Is it really finished?']
qText: Is it really finished?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Quite finished,', 'And you have sat splendidly\nto-day. I am awfully obliged to you.']
qText:
Quite finished, And you have sat splendidly
to-day. I am awfully obliged to you.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['That is entirely due to me,', 'Isn t it, Mr.\nGray?']
qText:
That is entirely due to me, Isn t it, Mr.
Gray?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Don t you like it?']
qText: Don t you like it?
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Of course he likes it,', 'Who wouldn t like it? It is\none of the greatest things in modern art. I will give you anything you\nlike to ask for it. I must have it.']
qText:
Of course he likes it, Who wouldn t like it? It is
one of the greatest things in modern art. I will give you anything you
like to ask for it. I must have it.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['It is not my property, Harry.']
qText: It is not my property, Harry.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Whose property is it?']
qText: Whose property is it?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Dorian s, of course,']
qText: Dorian s, of course,
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['He is a very lucky fellow.']
qText: He is a very lucky fellow.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['How sad it is!', 'How sad it is! I shall grow old, and horrible, and
dreadful. But this picture will remain always young. It will never be
older than this particular day of June.... If it were only the other
way! If it were I who was to be always young, and the picture that was
to grow old! For that for that I would give everything! Yes, there is
nothing in the whole world I would not give! I would give my soul for
that!']
qText:
How sad it is! How sad it is! I shall grow old, and horrible, and
dreadful. But this picture will remain always young. It will never be
older than this particular day of June.... If it were only the other
way! If it were I who was to be always young, and the picture that was
to grow old! For that for that I would give everything! Yes, there is
nothing in the whole world I would not give! I would give my soul for
that!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You would hardly care for such an arrangement, Basil,', 'It would be rather hard lines on your work.']
qText: You would hardly care for such an arrangement, Basil, It would be rather hard lines on your work.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I should object very strongly, Harry,']
qText: I should object very strongly, Harry,
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I believe you would, Basil. You\nlike your art better than your friends. I am no more to you than a\ngreen bronze figure. Hardly as much, I dare say.']
qText:
I believe you would, Basil. You
like your art better than your friends. I am no more to you than a
green bronze figure. Hardly as much, I dare say.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward']]]

qTextArr:
['Yes,', 'I am less to you than your ivory Hermes or your
silver Faun. You will like them always. How long will you like me? Till
I have my first wrinkle, I suppose. I know, now, that when one loses
one s good looks, whatever they may be, one loses everything. Your
picture has taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton is perfectly right. Youth
is the only thing worth having. When I find that I am growing old, I
shall kill myself.']
qText:
Yes, I am less to you than your ivory Hermes or your
silver Faun. You will like them always. How long will you like me? Till
I have my first wrinkle, I suppose. I know, now, that when one loses
one s good looks, whatever they may be, one loses everything. Your
picture has taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton is perfectly right. Youth
is the only thing worth having. When I find that I am growing old, I
shall kill myself.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[], [['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr: ['Dorian! Dorian!', 'don t talk like that. I have never had such a friend as you, and I\nshall never have such another. You are not jealous of material things,\nare you? you who are finer than any of them!']
qText:
Dorian! Dorian! don t talk like that. I have never had such a friend as you, and I
shall never have such another. You are not jealous of material things,
are you? you who are finer than any of them!
speaker: Basil Hallward
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']], [['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr:
['I am jealous of everything whose beauty does not die. I am jealous of
the portrait you have painted of me. Why should it keep what I must
lose? Every moment that passes takes something from me and gives
something to it. Oh, if it were only the other way! If the picture
could change, and I could be always what I am now! Why did you paint
it? It will mock me some day mock me horribly!']
qText:
I am jealous of everything whose beauty does not die. I am jealous of
the portrait you have painted of me. Why should it keep what I must
lose? Every moment that passes takes something from me and gives
something to it. Oh, if it were only the other way! If the picture
could change, and I could be always what I am now! Why did you paint
it? It will mock me some day mock me horribly!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['This is your doing, Harry,']
qText: This is your doing, Harry,
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['It is the real Dorian Gray that is\nall.']
qText:
It is the real Dorian Gray that is
all.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['It is not.']
qText: It is not.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['If it is not, what have I to do with it?']
qText: If it is not, what have I to do with it?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You should have gone away when I asked you,']
qText: You should have gone away when I asked you,
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I stayed when you asked me,']
qText: I stayed when you asked me,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Harry, I can t quarrel with my two best friends at once, but between
you both you have made me hate the finest piece of work I have ever
done, and I will destroy it. What is it but canvas and colour? I will
not let it come across our three lives and mar them.']
qText:
Harry, I can t quarrel with my two best friends at once, but between
you both you have made me hate the finest piece of work I have ever
done, and I will destroy it. What is it but canvas and colour? I will
not let it come across our three lives and mar them.
speaker: Basil Hallward
menEnts: [[['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Henry'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Basil Hallward'], ['Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr: ['Don t, Basil, don t!', 'It would be murder!']
qText: Don t, Basil, don t! It would be murder!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I am glad you appreciate my work at last, Dorian,', 'I never thought you\nwould.']
qText:
I am glad you appreciate my work at last, Dorian, I never thought you
would.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Appreciate it? I am in love with it, Basil. It is part of myself. I\nfeel that.']
qText:
Appreciate it? I am in love with it, Basil. It is part of myself. I
feel that.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Well, as soon as you are dry, you shall be varnished, and framed, and\nsent home. Then you can do what you like with yourself.']
qText:
Well, as soon as you are dry, you shall be varnished, and framed, and
sent home. Then you can do what you like with yourself.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['You will have tea, of\ncourse, Dorian? And so will you, Harry? Or do you object to such simple\npleasures?']
qText:
You will have tea, of
course, Dorian? And so will you, Harry? Or do you object to such simple
pleasures?
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr:
['I adore simple pleasures,', 'They are the last refuge
of the complex. But I don t like scenes, except on the stage. What
absurd fellows you are, both of you! I wonder who it was defined man as
a rational animal. It was the most premature definition ever given. Man
is many things, but he is not rational. I am glad he is not, after
all though I wish you chaps would not squabble over the picture. You
had much better let me have it, Basil. This silly boy doesn t really
want it, and I really do.']
qText:
I adore simple pleasures, They are the last refuge
of the complex. But I don t like scenes, except on the stage. What
absurd fellows you are, both of you! I wonder who it was defined man as
a rational animal. It was the most premature definition ever given. Man
is many things, but he is not rational. I am glad he is not, after
all though I wish you chaps would not squabble over the picture. You
had much better let me have it, Basil. This silly boy doesn t really
want it, and I really do.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[], [['Dorian Gray', 'Basil Hallward'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward', 'Dorian Gray'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['If you let any one have it but me, Basil, I shall never forgive you!', 'and I don t allow people to call me a silly boy.']
qText: If you let any one have it but me, Basil, I shall never forgive you! and I don t allow people to call me a silly boy.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You know the picture is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it\nexisted.']
qText:
You know the picture is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it
existed.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['And you know you have been a little silly, Mr. Gray, and that you\ndon t really object to being reminded that you are extremely young.']
qText:
And you know you have been a little silly, Mr. Gray, and that you
don t really object to being reminded that you are extremely young.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I should have objected very strongly this morning, Lord Henry.']
qText: I should have objected very strongly this morning, Lord Henry.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Ah! this morning! You have lived since then.']
qText: Ah! this morning! You have lived since then.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Let us go to the theatre to-night,', 'There is sure to
be something on, somewhere. I have promised to dine at White s, but it
is only with an old friend, so I can send him a wire to say that I am
ill, or that I am prevented from coming in consequence of a subsequent
engagement. I think that would be a rather nice excuse: it would have
all the surprise of candour.']
qText:
Let us go to the theatre to-night, There is sure to
be something on, somewhere. I have promised to dine at White s, but it
is only with an old friend, so I can send him a wire to say that I am
ill, or that I am prevented from coming in consequence of a subsequent
engagement. I think that would be a rather nice excuse: it would have
all the surprise of candour.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['It is such a bore putting on one s dress-clothes,', 'And, when one has them on, they are so horrid.']
qText: It is such a bore putting on one s dress-clothes, And, when one has them on, they are so horrid.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'the costume of the nineteenth\ncentury is detestable. It is so sombre, so depressing. Sin is the only\nreal colour-element left in modern life.']
qText:
Yes, the costume of the nineteenth
century is detestable. It is so sombre, so depressing. Sin is the only
real colour-element left in modern life.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You really must not say things like that before Dorian, Harry.']
qText: You really must not say things like that before Dorian, Harry.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Before which Dorian? The one who is pouring out tea for us, or the one\nin the picture?']
qText:
Before which Dorian? The one who is pouring out tea for us, or the one
in the picture?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Before either.']
qText: Before either.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I should like to come to the theatre with you, Lord Henry,']
qText: I should like to come to the theatre with you, Lord Henry,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Then you shall come; and you will come, too, Basil, won t you?']
qText: Then you shall come; and you will come, too, Basil, won t you?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I can t, really. I would sooner not. I have a lot of work to do.']
qText: I can t, really. I would sooner not. I have a lot of work to do.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Well, then, you and I will go alone, Mr. Gray.']
qText: Well, then, you and I will go alone, Mr. Gray.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I should like that awfully.']
qText: I should like that awfully.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I shall stay with the real Dorian,']
qText: I shall stay with the real Dorian,
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Is it the real Dorian?', 'Am I really like that?']
qText: Is it the real Dorian? Am I really like that?
speaker: Dorian Gray
refExp: cried the original of the portrait

qTextArr: ['Yes; you are just like that.']
qText: Yes; you are just like that.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['How wonderful, Basil!']
qText: How wonderful, Basil!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['At least you are like it in appearance. But it will never alter,', 'That is something.']
qText: At least you are like it in appearance. But it will never alter, That is something.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr:
['What a fuss people make about fidelity!', 'Why,
even in love it is purely a question for physiology. It has nothing to
do with our own will. Young men want to be faithful, and are not; old
men want to be faithless, and cannot: that is all one can say.']
qText:
What a fuss people make about fidelity! Why,
even in love it is purely a question for physiology. It has nothing to
do with our own will. Young men want to be faithful, and are not; old
men want to be faithless, and cannot: that is all one can say.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Don t go to the theatre to-night, Dorian,', 'Stop and\ndine with me.']
qText:
Don t go to the theatre to-night, Dorian, Stop and
dine with me.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I can t, Basil.']
qText: I can t, Basil.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qText: Why?
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Because I have promised Lord Henry Wotton to go with him.']
qText: Because I have promised Lord Henry Wotton to go with him.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['He won t like you the better for keeping your promises. He always\nbreaks his own. I beg you not to go.']
qText:
He won t like you the better for keeping your promises. He always
breaks his own. I beg you not to go.
speaker: Basil Hallward
menEnts: [[['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['I entreat you.']
qText: I entreat you.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I must go, Basil,']
qText: I must go, Basil,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Very well,', 'It is rather late, and, as you have to dress, you had better\nlose no time. Good-bye, Harry. Good-bye, Dorian. Come and see me soon.\nCome to-morrow.']
qText:
Very well, It is rather late, and, as you have to dress, you had better
lose no time. Good-bye, Harry. Good-bye, Dorian. Come and see me soon.
Come to-morrow.
speaker: Basil Hallward
menEnts: [[], [['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['Certainly.']
qText: Certainly.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You won t forget?']
qText: You won t forget?
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['No, of course not,']
qText: No, of course not,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['And ... Harry!']
qText: And ... Harry!
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Yes, Basil?']
qText: Yes, Basil?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Remember what I asked you, when we were in the garden this morning.']
qText: Remember what I asked you, when we were in the garden this morning.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I have forgotten it.']
qText: I have forgotten it.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I trust you.']
qText: I trust you.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I wish I could trust myself,', 'Come, Mr.\nGray, my hansom is outside, and I can drop you at your own place.\nGood-bye, Basil. It has been a most interesting afternoon.']
qText:
I wish I could trust myself, Come, Mr.
Gray, my hansom is outside, and I can drop you at your own place.
Good-bye, Basil. It has been a most interesting afternoon.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Well,
Harry,', 'what brings you out so early? I
thought you dandies never got up till two, and were not visible till
five.']
qText:
Well,
Harry, what brings you out so early? I
thought you dandies never got up till two, and were not visible till
five.
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['Pure family affection, I assure you, Uncle George. I want to get\nsomething out of you.']
qText:
Pure family affection, I assure you, Uncle George. I want to get
something out of you.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Money, I suppose,', 'Well, sit\ndown and tell me all about it. Young people, nowadays, imagine that\nmoney is everything.']
qText:
Money, I suppose, Well, sit
down and tell me all about it. Young people, nowadays, imagine that
money is everything.
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr:
['Yes,', 'and
when they grow older they know it. But I don t want money. It is only
people who pay their bills who want that, Uncle George, and I never pay
mine. Credit is the capital of a younger son, and one lives charmingly
upon it. Besides, I always deal with Dartmoor s tradesmen, and
consequently they never bother me. What I want is information: not
useful information, of course; useless information.']
qText:
Yes, and
when they grow older they know it. But I don t want money. It is only
people who pay their bills who want that, Uncle George, and I never pay
mine. Credit is the capital of a younger son, and one lives charmingly
upon it. Besides, I always deal with Dartmoor s tradesmen, and
consequently they never bother me. What I want is information: not
useful information, of course; useless information.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Well, I can tell you anything that is in an English Blue Book, Harry,
although those fellows nowadays write a lot of nonsense. When I was in
the Diplomatic, things were much better. But I hear they let them in
now by examination. What can you expect? Examinations, sir, are pure
humbug from beginning to end. If a man is a gentleman, he knows quite
enough, and if he is not a gentleman, whatever he knows is bad for
him.']
qText:
Well, I can tell you anything that is in an English Blue Book, Harry,
although those fellows nowadays write a lot of nonsense. When I was in
the Diplomatic, things were much better. But I hear they let them in
now by examination. What can you expect? Examinations, sir, are pure
humbug from beginning to end. If a man is a gentleman, he knows quite
enough, and if he is not a gentleman, whatever he knows is bad for
him.
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['Mr. Dorian Gray does not belong to Blue Books, Uncle George,']
qText: Mr. Dorian Gray does not belong to Blue Books, Uncle George,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he?']
qText: Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he?
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr:
['That is what I have come to learn, Uncle George. Or rather, I know who
he is. He is the last Lord Kelso s grandson. His mother was a Devereux,
Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What
was she like? Whom did she marry? You have known nearly everybody in
your time, so you might have known her. I am very much interested in
Mr. Gray at present. I have only just met him.']
qText:
That is what I have come to learn, Uncle George. Or rather, I know who
he is. He is the last Lord Kelso s grandson. His mother was a Devereux,
Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What
was she like? Whom did she marry? You have known nearly everybody in
your time, so you might have known her. I am very much interested in
Mr. Gray at present. I have only just met him.
speaker: Lord Henry
menTexts: [['Uncle George', 'he', 'He', 'the last Lord Kelso s grandson', 'His', 'you', 'his', 'You', 'your', 'you', 'Mr. Gray', 'him']]
menEnts: [[['Lord Fermor'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Fermor'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Fermor'], ['Lord Fermor'], ['Lord Fermor'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr:
['Kelso s grandson!', 'Kelso s grandson! ... Of
course.... I knew his mother intimately. I believe I was at her
christening. She was an extraordinarily beautiful girl, Margaret
Devereux, and made all the men frantic by running away with a penniless
young fellow a mere nobody, sir, a subaltern in a foot regiment, or
something of that kind. Certainly. I remember the whole thing as if it
happened yesterday. The poor chap was killed in a duel at Spa a few
months after the marriage. There was an ugly story about it. They said
Kelso got some rascally adventurer, some Belgian brute, to insult his
son-in-law in public paid him, sir, to do it, paid him and that the
fellow spitted his man as if he had been a pigeon. The thing was hushed
up, but, egad, Kelso ate his chop alone at the club for some time
afterwards. He brought his daughter back with him, I was told, and she
never spoke to him again. Oh, yes; it was a bad business. The girl
died, too, died within a year. So she left a son, did she? I had
forgotten that. What sort of boy is he? If he is like his mother, he
must be a good-looking chap.']
qText:
Kelso s grandson! Kelso s grandson! ... Of
course.... I knew his mother intimately. I believe I was at her
christening. She was an extraordinarily beautiful girl, Margaret
Devereux, and made all the men frantic by running away with a penniless
young fellow a mere nobody, sir, a subaltern in a foot regiment, or
something of that kind. Certainly. I remember the whole thing as if it
happened yesterday. The poor chap was killed in a duel at Spa a few
months after the marriage. There was an ugly story about it. They said
Kelso got some rascally adventurer, some Belgian brute, to insult his
son-in-law in public paid him, sir, to do it, paid him and that the
fellow spitted his man as if he had been a pigeon. The thing was hushed
up, but, egad, Kelso ate his chop alone at the club for some time
afterwards. He brought his daughter back with him, I was told, and she
never spoke to him again. Oh, yes; it was a bad business. The girl
died, too, died within a year. So she left a son, did she? I had
forgotten that. What sort of boy is he? If he is like his mother, he
must be a good-looking chap.
speaker: Lord Fermor
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray']], [['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Henry'], ['Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['He is very good-looking,']
qText: He is very good-looking,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['I hope he will fall into proper hands,', 'He
should have a pot of money waiting for him if Kelso did the right thing
by him. His mother had money, too. All the Selby property came to her,
through her grandfather. Her grandfather hated Kelso, thought him a
mean dog. He was, too. Came to Madrid once when I was there. Egad, I
was ashamed of him. The Queen used to ask me about the English noble
who was always quarrelling with the cabmen about their fares. They made
quite a story of it. I didn t dare show my face at Court for a month. I
hope he treated his grandson better than he did the jarvies.']
qText:
I hope he will fall into proper hands, He
should have a pot of money waiting for him if Kelso did the right thing
by him. His mother had money, too. All the Selby property came to her,
through her grandfather. Her grandfather hated Kelso, thought him a
mean dog. He was, too. Came to Madrid once when I was there. Egad, I
was ashamed of him. The Queen used to ask me about the English noble
who was always quarrelling with the cabmen about their fares. They made
quite a story of it. I didn t dare show my face at Court for a month. I
hope he treated his grandson better than he did the jarvies.
speaker: Lord Fermor
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray']], [['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['I don t know,', 'I fancy that the boy will be well\noff. He is not of age yet. He has Selby, I know. He told me so. And ...\nhis mother was very beautiful?']
qText:
I don t know, I fancy that the boy will be well
off. He is not of age yet. He has Selby, I know. He told me so. And ...
his mother was very beautiful?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Margaret Devereux was one of the loveliest creatures I ever saw,
Harry. What on earth induced her to behave as she did, I never could
understand. She could have married anybody she chose. Carlington was
mad after her. She was romantic, though. All the women of that family
were. The men were a poor lot, but, egad! the women were wonderful.
Carlington went on his knees to her. Told me so himself. She laughed at
him, and there wasn t a girl in London at the time who wasn t after
him. And by the way, Harry, talking about silly marriages, what is this
humbug your father tells me about Dartmoor wanting to marry an
American? Ain t English girls good enough for him?']
qText:
Margaret Devereux was one of the loveliest creatures I ever saw,
Harry. What on earth induced her to behave as she did, I never could
understand. She could have married anybody she chose. Carlington was
mad after her. She was romantic, though. All the women of that family
were. The men were a poor lot, but, egad! the women were wonderful.
Carlington went on his knees to her. Told me so himself. She laughed at
him, and there wasn t a girl in London at the time who wasn t after
him. And by the way, Harry, talking about silly marriages, what is this
humbug your father tells me about Dartmoor wanting to marry an
American? Ain t English girls good enough for him?
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['It is rather fashionable to marry Americans just now, Uncle George.']
qText: It is rather fashionable to marry Americans just now, Uncle George.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I ll back English women against the world, Harry,']
qText: I ll back English women against the world, Harry,
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['The betting is on the Americans.']
qText: The betting is on the Americans.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['They don t last, I am told,']
qText: They don t last, I am told,
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['A long engagement exhausts them, but they are capital at a\nsteeplechase. They take things flying. I don t think Dartmoor has a\nchance.']
qText:
A long engagement exhausts them, but they are capital at a
steeplechase. They take things flying. I don t think Dartmoor has a
chance.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Who are her people?', 'Has she got any?']
qText: Who are her people? Has she got any?
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['American girls are as clever at concealing\ntheir parents, as English women are at concealing their past,']
qText:
American girls are as clever at concealing
their parents, as English women are at concealing their past,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['They are pork-packers, I suppose?']
qText: They are pork-packers, I suppose?
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['I hope so, Uncle George, for Dartmoor s sake. I am told that\npork-packing is the most lucrative profession in America, after\npolitics.']
qText:
I hope so, Uncle George, for Dartmoor s sake. I am told that
pork-packing is the most lucrative profession in America, after
politics.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Is she pretty?']
qText: Is she pretty?
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['She behaves as if she was beautiful. Most American women do. It is the\nsecret of their charm.']
qText:
She behaves as if she was beautiful. Most American women do. It is the
secret of their charm.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Why can t these American women stay in their own country? They are\nalways telling us that it is the paradise for women.']
qText:
Why can t these American women stay in their own country? They are
always telling us that it is the paradise for women.
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr:
['It is. That is the reason why, like Eve, they are so excessively
anxious to get out of it,', 'Good-bye, Uncle George. I
shall be late for lunch, if I stop any longer. Thanks for giving me the
information I wanted. I always like to know everything about my new
friends, and nothing about my old ones.']
qText:
It is. That is the reason why, like Eve, they are so excessively
anxious to get out of it, Good-bye, Uncle George. I
shall be late for lunch, if I stop any longer. Thanks for giving me the
information I wanted. I always like to know everything about my new
friends, and nothing about my old ones.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Where are you lunching, Harry?']
qText: Where are you lunching, Harry?
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['At Aunt Agatha s. I have asked myself and Mr. Gray. He is her latest\n_prot g _.']
qText:
At Aunt Agatha s. I have asked myself and Mr. Gray. He is her latest
_prot g _.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Humph! tell your Aunt Agatha, Harry, not to bother me any more with\nher charity appeals. I am sick of them. Why, the good woman thinks that\nI have nothing to do but to write cheques for her silly fads.']
qText:
Humph! tell your Aunt Agatha, Harry, not to bother me any more with
her charity appeals. I am sick of them. Why, the good woman thinks that
I have nothing to do but to write cheques for her silly fads.
speaker: Lord Fermor

qTextArr: ['All right, Uncle George, I ll tell her, but it won t have any effect.\nPhilanthropic people lose all sense of humanity. It is their\ndistinguishing characteristic.']
qText:
All right, Uncle George, I ll tell her, but it won t have any effect.
Philanthropic people lose all sense of humanity. It is their
distinguishing characteristic.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Late as usual, Harry,']
qText: Late as usual, Harry,
speaker: Lady Agatha

qTextArr: ['We are talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry,', 'Do you think he will\nreally marry this fascinating young person?']
qText:
We are talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry, Do you think he will

I am told, on excellent authority, that her father keeps an American

qTextArr: ['When America was discovered,']

qTextArr: ['I wish to goodness it never had been\ndiscovered at all!', 'Really, our girls have no chance\nnowadays. It is most unfair.']

I wish to goodness it never had been
discovered at all! Really, our girls have no chance
nowadays. It is most unfair.

qTextArr: ['Perhaps, after all, America never has been discovered,', 'I myself would say that it had merely been detected.']

qTextArr: ['Oh! but I have seen specimens of the inhabitants,', 'I must confess that most of them are extremely\npretty. And they dress well, too. They get all their dresses in Paris.\nI wish I could afford to do the same.']
qText:
Oh! but I have seen specimens of the inhabitants, I must confess that most of them are extremely
pretty. And they dress well, too. They get all their dresses in Paris.
I wish I could afford to do the same.
speaker: Duchess Of Harley
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['They say that when good Americans die they go to Paris,']
qText: They say that when good Americans die they go to Paris,

addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley']

qTextArr: ['Really! And where do bad Americans go to when they die?']
qText: Really! And where do bad Americans go to when they die?
speaker: Duchess Of Harley
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['They go to America,']
qText: They go to America,
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr:
['I am afraid that your nephew is prejudiced against
that great country,', 'I have travelled all over
it in cars provided by the directors, who, in such matters, are
extremely civil. I assure you that it is an education to visit it.']
qText:
I am afraid that your nephew is prejudiced against
that great country, I have travelled all over
it in cars provided by the directors, who, in such matters, are
extremely civil. I assure you that it is an education to visit it.
speaker: Sir Thomas Burdon
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley']

qTextArr: ['But must we really see Chicago in order to be educated?', 'I don t feel up to the journey.']
qText: But must we really see Chicago in order to be educated? I don t feel up to the journey.
speaker: Mr. Erskine
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr:
['Mr. Erskine of Treadley has the world on
his shelves. We practical men like to see things, not to read about
them. The Americans are an extremely interesting people. They are
absolutely reasonable. I think that is their distinguishing
characteristic. Yes, Mr. Erskine, an absolutely reasonable people. I
assure you there is no nonsense about the Americans.']
qText:
Mr. Erskine of Treadley has the world on
his shelves. We practical men like to see things, not to read about
them. The Americans are an extremely interesting people. They are
absolutely reasonable. I think that is their distinguishing
characteristic. Yes, Mr. Erskine, an absolutely reasonable people. I
assure you there is no nonsense about the Americans.
speaker: Sir Thomas Burdon
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley']

qTextArr: ['How dreadful!', 'I can stand brute force, but brute\nreason is quite unbearable. There is something unfair about its use. It\nis hitting below the intellect.']
qText:
How dreadful! I can stand brute force, but brute
reason is quite unbearable. There is something unfair about its use. It
is hitting below the intellect.
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['I do not understand you,']
qText: I do not understand you,
speaker: Sir Thomas Burdon
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley']

qTextArr: ['I do, Lord Henry,']
qText: I do, Lord Henry,
speaker: Mr. Erskine
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['Paradoxes are all very well in their way....']
qText: Paradoxes are all very well in their way....
speaker: Sir Thomas Burdon
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley']

qTextArr:
['Was that a paradox?', 'I did not think so. Perhaps
it was. Well, the way of paradoxes is the way of truth. To test reality
we must see it on the tight rope. When the verities become acrobats, we
can judge them.']
qText:
Was that a paradox? I did not think so. Perhaps
it was. Well, the way of paradoxes is the way of truth. To test reality
we must see it on the tight rope. When the verities become acrobats, we
can judge them.
speaker: Mr. Erskine
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr:
['Dear me!', 'how you men argue! I am sure I never can
make out what you are talking about. Oh! Harry, I am quite vexed with
you. Why do you try to persuade our nice Mr. Dorian Gray to give up the
East End? I assure you he would be quite invaluable. They would love
his playing.']
qText:
Dear me! how you men argue! I am sure I never can
make out what you are talking about. Oh! Harry, I am quite vexed with
you. Why do you try to persuade our nice Mr. Dorian Gray to give up the
East End? I assure you he would be quite invaluable. They would love
his playing.
speaker: Lady Agatha
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']
menTexts: [[], ['you men', 'you', 'Harry', 'you', 'you', 'our nice Mr. Dorian Gray', 'Mr. Dorian ', 'you', 'he', 'They', 'his']]
menEnts: [[], [['Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon'], ['Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['I want him to play to me,']
qText: I want him to play to me,
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['But they are so unhappy in Whitechapel,']
qText: But they are so unhappy in Whitechapel,
speaker: Lady Agatha
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr:
['I can sympathize with everything except suffering,', 'I cannot sympathize with that. It is too
ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid
in the modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathize with the
colour, the beauty, the joy of life. The less said about life s sores,
the better.']
qText:
I can sympathize with everything except suffering, I cannot sympathize with that. It is too
ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid
in the modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathize with the
colour, the beauty, the joy of life. The less said about life s sores,
the better.
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['Still, the East End is a very important problem,']
qText: Still, the East End is a very important problem,
speaker: Sir Thomas Burdon
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley']

qTextArr: ['Quite so,', 'It is the problem of slavery, and\nwe try to solve it by amusing the slaves.']
qText:
Quite so, It is the problem of slavery, and
we try to solve it by amusing the slaves.
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']
menEnts: [[], [['Dorian Gray', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Henry', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']]]

qTextArr: ['What change do you propose,\nthen?']
qText:
What change do you propose,
then?
speaker: Sir Thomas Burdon
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley']

qTextArr:
['I don t desire to change anything in England
except the weather,', 'I am quite content with philosophic
contemplation. But, as the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt through
an over-expenditure of sympathy, I would suggest that we should appeal
to science to put us straight. The advantage of the emotions is that
they lead us astray, and the advantage of science is that it is not
emotional.']
qText:
I don t desire to change anything in England
except the weather, I am quite content with philosophic
contemplation. But, as the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt through
an over-expenditure of sympathy, I would suggest that we should appeal
to science to put us straight. The advantage of the emotions is that
they lead us astray, and the advantage of science is that it is not
emotional.
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['But we have such grave responsibilities,']
qText: But we have such grave responsibilities,
speaker: Mrs. Vandeleur
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['Terribly grave,']
qText: Terribly grave,
speaker: Lady Agatha
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['Humanity takes itself too\nseriously. It is the world s original sin. If the caveman had known how\nto laugh, history would have been different.']
qText:
Humanity takes itself too
seriously. It is the world s original sin. If the caveman had known how
to laugh, history would have been different.
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr:
['You are really very comforting,', 'I have always
felt rather guilty when I came to see your dear aunt, for I take no
interest at all in the East End. For the future I shall be able to look
her in the face without a blush.']
qText:
You are really very comforting, I have always
felt rather guilty when I came to see your dear aunt, for I take no
interest at all in the East End. For the future I shall be able to look
her in the face without a blush.
speaker: Duchess Of Harley
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['A blush is very becoming, Duchess,']
qText: A blush is very becoming, Duchess,
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['Only when one is young,', 'When an old woman like myself\nblushes, it is a very bad sign. Ah! Lord Henry, I wish you would tell\nme how to become young again.']
qText:
Only when one is young, When an old woman like myself
blushes, it is a very bad sign. Ah! Lord Henry, I wish you would tell
me how to become young again.
speaker: Duchess Of Harley
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['Can you remember any great error that you\ncommitted in your early days, Duchess?']
qText:
Can you remember any great error that you
committed in your early days, Duchess?
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']
menEnts: [[['Duchess Of Harley'], ['Duchess Of Harley'], ['Duchess Of Harley'], ['Duchess Of Harley']]]

qTextArr: ['A great many, I fear,']
qText: A great many, I fear,
speaker: Duchess Of Harley
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['Then commit them over again,', 'To get back one s\nyouth, one has merely to repeat one s follies.']
qText:
Then commit them over again, To get back one s
youth, one has merely to repeat one s follies.
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['A delightful theory!', 'I must put it into practice.']
qText: A delightful theory! I must put it into practice.
speaker: Duchess Of Harley
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['A dangerous theory!']
qText: A dangerous theory!
speaker: Sir Thomas Burdon
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Harley']

qTextArr:
['Yes,', 'that is one of the great secrets of life.
Nowadays most people die of a sort of creeping common sense, and
discover when it is too late that the only things one never regrets are
one s mistakes.']
qText:
Yes, that is one of the great secrets of life.
Nowadays most people die of a sort of creeping common sense, and
discover when it is too late that the only things one never regrets are
one s mistakes.
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr:
['How annoying!', 'I must go. I have to call for my husband at the club, to take
him to some absurd meeting at Willis s Rooms, where he is going to be
in the chair. If I am late he is sure to be furious, and I couldn t
have a scene in this bonnet. It is far too fragile. A harsh word would
ruin it. No, I must go, dear Agatha. Good-bye, Lord Henry, you are
quite delightful and dreadfully demoralizing. I am sure I don t know
what to say about your views. You must come and dine with us some
night. Tuesday? Are you disengaged Tuesday?']
qText:
How annoying! I must go. I have to call for my husband at the club, to take
him to some absurd meeting at Willis s Rooms, where he is going to be
in the chair. If I am late he is sure to be furious, and I couldn t
have a scene in this bonnet. It is far too fragile. A harsh word would
ruin it. No, I must go, dear Agatha. Good-bye, Lord Henry, you are
quite delightful and dreadfully demoralizing. I am sure I don t know
what to say about your views. You must come and dine with us some
night. Tuesday? Are you disengaged Tuesday?
speaker: Duchess Of Harley
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']
menEnts: [[], [['Lady Agatha'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Duchess Of Harley'], ['Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr: ['For you I would throw over anybody, Duchess,']
qText: For you I would throw over anybody, Duchess,
speaker: Lord Henry
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['Ah! that is very nice, and very wrong of you,', 'so mind you\ncome']
qText:
Ah! that is very nice, and very wrong of you, so mind you
come
speaker: Duchess Of Harley
addressee: ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Lord Henry', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']

qTextArr: ['You talk books away,', 'why don t you write one?']
qText: You talk books away, why don t you write one?
speaker: Mr. Erskine

qTextArr:
['I am too fond of reading books to care to write them, Mr. Erskine. I
should like to write a novel certainly, a novel that would be as lovely
as a Persian carpet and as unreal. But there is no literary public in
England for anything except newspapers, primers, and encyclopaedias. Of
all people in the world the English have the least sense of the beauty
of literature.']
qText:
I am too fond of reading books to care to write them, Mr. Erskine. I
should like to write a novel certainly, a novel that would be as lovely
as a Persian carpet and as unreal. But there is no literary public in
England for anything except newspapers, primers, and encyclopaedias. Of
all people in the world the English have the least sense of the beauty
of literature.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['I fear you are right,', 'I myself used to have
literary ambitions, but I gave them up long ago. And now, my dear young
friend, if you will allow me to call you so, may I ask if you really
meant all that you said to us at lunch?']
qText:
I fear you are right, I myself used to have
literary ambitions, but I gave them up long ago. And now, my dear young
friend, if you will allow me to call you so, may I ask if you really
meant all that you said to us at lunch?
speaker: Mr. Erskine
menEnts: [[['Lord Henry']], [['Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Mrs. Vandeleur', 'Lady Agatha', 'Mr. Erskine', 'Duchess Of Harley', 'Sir Thomas Burdon']]]

qTextArr: ['I quite forget what I said,', 'Was it all very bad?']
qText: I quite forget what I said, Was it all very bad?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Very bad indeed. In fact I consider you extremely dangerous, and if
anything happens to our good duchess, we shall all look on you as being
primarily responsible. But I should like to talk to you about life. The
generation into which I was born was tedious. Some day, when you are
tired of London, come down to Treadley and expound to me your
philosophy of pleasure over some admirable Burgundy I am fortunate
enough to possess.']
qText:
Very bad indeed. In fact I consider you extremely dangerous, and if
anything happens to our good duchess, we shall all look on you as being
primarily responsible. But I should like to talk to you about life. The
generation into which I was born was tedious. Some day, when you are
tired of London, come down to Treadley and expound to me your
philosophy of pleasure over some admirable Burgundy I am fortunate
enough to possess.
speaker: Mr. Erskine
menEnts: [[['Lord Henry'], ['Duchess Of Harley'], ['Mr. Erskine'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr: ['I shall be charmed. A visit to Treadley would be a great privilege. It\nhas a perfect host, and a perfect library.']
qText:
I shall be charmed. A visit to Treadley would be a great privilege. It
has a perfect host, and a perfect library.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You will complete it,', 'And now I must bid good-bye to your excellent aunt. I am due at\nthe Athenaeum. It is the hour when we sleep there.']
qText:
You will complete it, And now I must bid good-bye to your excellent aunt. I am due at
the Athenaeum. It is the hour when we sleep there.
speaker: Mr. Erskine

qTextArr: ['All of you, Mr. Erskine?']
qText: All of you, Mr. Erskine?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Forty of us, in forty arm-chairs. We are practising for an English\nAcademy of Letters.']
qText:
Forty of us, in forty arm-chairs. We are practising for an English
Academy of Letters.
speaker: Mr. Erskine

qTextArr: ['I am going to the park,']
qText: I am going to the park,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Let me come with you,']
qText: Let me come with you,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['But I thought you had promised Basil Hallward to go and see him,']
qText: But I thought you had promised Basil Hallward to go and see him,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I would sooner come with you; yes, I feel I must come with you. Do let\nme. And you will promise to talk to me all the time? No one talks so\nwonderfully as you do.']
qText:
I would sooner come with you; yes, I feel I must come with you. Do let
me. And you will promise to talk to me all the time? No one talks so
wonderfully as you do.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Ah! I have talked quite enough for to-day,', 'All I want now is to look at life. You may come and look at it with\nme, if you care to.']
qText:
Ah! I have talked quite enough for to-day, All I want now is to look at life. You may come and look at it with
me, if you care to.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['How late you\nare, Harry!']
qText:
How late you
are, Harry!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I am afraid it is not Harry, Mr. Gray,']
qText: I am afraid it is not Harry, Mr. Gray,
speaker: Lady Henry

qTextArr: ['I beg your pardon. I\nthought']
qText:
I beg your pardon. I
thought
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You thought it was my husband. It is only his wife. You must let me\nintroduce myself. I know you quite well by your photographs. I think my\nhusband has got seventeen of them.']
qText:
You thought it was my husband. It is only his wife. You must let me
introduce myself. I know you quite well by your photographs. I think my
husband has got seventeen of them.
speaker: Lady Henry

qTextArr: ['Not seventeen, Lady Henry?']
qText: Not seventeen, Lady Henry?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Well, eighteen, then. And I saw you with him the other night at the\nopera.']
qText:
Well, eighteen, then. And I saw you with him the other night at the
opera.
speaker: Lady Henry

qTextArr: ['That was at Lohengrin, Lady Henry, I think?']
qText: That was at Lohengrin, Lady Henry, I think?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Yes; it was at dear Lohengrin. I like Wagner s music better than
anybody s. It is so loud that one can talk the whole time without other
people hearing what one says. That is a great advantage, don t you
think so, Mr. Gray?']
qText:
Yes; it was at dear Lohengrin. I like Wagner s music better than
anybody s. It is so loud that one can talk the whole time without other
people hearing what one says. That is a great advantage, don t you
think so, Mr. Gray?
speaker: Lady Henry

qTextArr: ['I am afraid I don t think so, Lady\nHenry. I never talk during music at least, during good music. If one\nhears bad music, it is one s duty to drown it in conversation.']
qText:
I am afraid I don t think so, Lady
Henry. I never talk during music at least, during good music. If one
hears bad music, it is one s duty to drown it in conversation.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Ah! that is one of Harry s views, isn t it, Mr. Gray? I always hear
Harry s views from his friends. It is the only way I get to know of
them. But you must not think I don t like good music. I adore it, but I
am afraid of it. It makes me too romantic. I have simply worshipped
pianists two at a time, sometimes, Harry tells me. I don t know what it
is about them. Perhaps it is that they are foreigners. They all are,
ain t they? Even those that are born in England become foreigners after
a time, don t they? It is so clever of them, and such a compliment to
art. Makes it quite cosmopolitan, doesn t it? You have never been to
any of my parties, have you, Mr. Gray? You must come. I can t afford
orchids, but I spare no expense in foreigners. They make one s rooms
look so picturesque. But here is Harry! Harry, I came in to look for
you, to ask you something I forget what it was and I found Mr. Gray
here. We have had such a pleasant chat about music. We have quite the
same ideas. No; I think our ideas are quite different. But he has been
most pleasant. I am so glad I ve seen him.']
qText:
Ah! that is one of Harry s views, isn t it, Mr. Gray? I always hear
Harry s views from his friends. It is the only way I get to know of
them. But you must not think I don t like good music. I adore it, but I
am afraid of it. It makes me too romantic. I have simply worshipped
pianists two at a time, sometimes, Harry tells me. I don t know what it
is about them. Perhaps it is that they are foreigners. They all are,
ain t they? Even those that are born in England become foreigners after
a time, don t they? It is so clever of them, and such a compliment to
art. Makes it quite cosmopolitan, doesn t it? You have never been to
any of my parties, have you, Mr. Gray? You must come. I can t afford
orchids, but I spare no expense in foreigners. They make one s rooms
look so picturesque. But here is Harry! Harry, I came in to look for
you, to ask you something I forget what it was and I found Mr. Gray
here. We have had such a pleasant chat about music. We have quite the
same ideas. No; I think our ideas are quite different. But he has been
most pleasant. I am so glad I ve seen him.
speaker: Lady Henry
menEnts: [[['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lady Henry'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lady Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['I am charmed, my love, quite charmed,', 'So sorry I am late, Dorian. I went to look after a piece of old\nbrocade in Wardour Street and had to bargain for hours for it. Nowadays\npeople know the price of everything and the value of nothing.']
qText:
I am charmed, my love, quite charmed, So sorry I am late, Dorian. I went to look after a piece of old
brocade in Wardour Street and had to bargain for hours for it. Nowadays
people know the price of everything and the value of nothing.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I am afraid I must be going,', 'I have promised to drive\nwith the duchess. Good-bye, Mr. Gray. Good-bye, Harry. You are dining\nout, I suppose? So am I. Perhaps I shall see you at Lady Thornbury s.']
qText:
I am afraid I must be going, I have promised to drive
with the duchess. Good-bye, Mr. Gray. Good-bye, Harry. You are dining
out, I suppose? So am I. Perhaps I shall see you at Lady Thornbury s.
speaker: Lady Henry
menEnts: [[], [['Duchess Of Harley'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr: ['I dare say, my dear,']
qText: I dare say, my dear,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Never marry a woman with straw-coloured hair, Dorian,']
qText: Never marry a woman with straw-coloured hair, Dorian,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Why, Harry?']
qText: Why, Harry?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Because they are so sentimental.']
qText: Because they are so sentimental.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['But I like sentimental people.']
qText: But I like sentimental people.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Never marry at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women,\nbecause they are curious: both are disappointed.']
qText:
Never marry at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women,
because they are curious: both are disappointed.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I don t think I am likely to marry, Harry. I am too much in love. That\nis one of your aphorisms. I am putting it into practice, as I do\neverything that you say.']
qText:
I don t think I am likely to marry, Harry. I am too much in love. That
is one of your aphorisms. I am putting it into practice, as I do
everything that you say.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Who are you in love with?']
qText: Who are you in love with?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['With an actress,']
qText: With an actress,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['That is a rather commonplace\n_d but_.']
qText:
That is a rather commonplace
_d but_.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You would not say so if you saw her, Harry.']
qText: You would not say so if you saw her, Harry.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Who is she?']
qText: Who is she?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Her name is Sibyl Vane.']
qText: Her name is Sibyl Vane.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Never heard of her.']
qText: Never heard of her.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['No one has. People will some day, however. She is a genius.']
qText: No one has. People will some day, however. She is a genius.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['My dear boy, no woman is a genius. Women are a decorative sex. They
never have anything to say, but they say it charmingly. Women represent
the triumph of matter over mind, just as men represent the triumph of
mind over morals.']
qText:
My dear boy, no woman is a genius. Women are a decorative sex. They
never have anything to say, but they say it charmingly. Women represent
the triumph of matter over mind, just as men represent the triumph of
mind over morals.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Harry, how can you?']
qText: Harry, how can you?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['My dear Dorian, it is quite true. I am analysing women at present, so
I ought to know. The subject is not so abstruse as I thought it was. I
find that, ultimately, there are only two kinds of women, the plain and
the coloured. The plain women are very useful. If you want to gain a
reputation for respectability, you have merely to take them down to
supper. The other women are very charming. They commit one mistake,
however. They paint in order to try and look young. Our grandmothers
painted in order to try and talk brilliantly. _Rouge_ and _esprit_ used
to go together. That is all over now. As long as a woman can look ten
years younger than her own daughter, she is perfectly satisfied. As for
conversation, there are only five women in London worth talking to, and
two of these can t be admitted into decent society. However, tell me
about your genius. How long have you known her?']
qText:
My dear Dorian, it is quite true. I am analysing women at present, so
I ought to know. The subject is not so abstruse as I thought it was. I
find that, ultimately, there are only two kinds of women, the plain and
the coloured. The plain women are very useful. If you want to gain a
reputation for respectability, you have merely to take them down to
supper. The other women are very charming. They commit one mistake,
however. They paint in order to try and look young. Our grandmothers
painted in order to try and talk brilliantly. _Rouge_ and _esprit_ used
to go together. That is all over now. As long as a woman can look ten
years younger than her own daughter, she is perfectly satisfied. As for
conversation, there are only five women in London worth talking to, and
two of these can t be admitted into decent society. However, tell me
about your genius. How long have you known her?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Ah! Harry, your views terrify me.']
qText: Ah! Harry, your views terrify me.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Never mind that. How long have you known her?']
qText: Never mind that. How long have you known her?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['About three weeks.']
qText: About three weeks.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['And where did you come across her?']
qText: And where did you come across her?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['I will tell you, Harry, but you mustn t be unsympathetic about it.
After all, it never would have happened if I had not met you. You
filled me with a wild desire to know everything about life. For days
after I met you, something seemed to throb in my veins. As I lounged in
the park, or strolled down Piccadilly, I used to look at every one who
passed me and wonder, with a mad curiosity, what sort of lives they
led. Some of them fascinated me. Others filled me with terror. There
was an exquisite poison in the air. I had a passion for sensations....
Well, one evening about seven o clock, I determined to go out in search
of some adventure. I felt that this grey monstrous London of ours, with
its myriads of people, its sordid sinners, and its splendid sins, as
you once phrased it, must have something in store for me. I fancied a
thousand things. The mere danger gave me a sense of delight. I
remembered what you had said to me on that wonderful evening when we
first dined together, about the search for beauty being the real secret
of life. I don t know what I expected, but I went out and wandered
eastward, soon losing my way in a labyrinth of grimy streets and black
grassless squares. About half-past eight I passed by an absurd little
theatre, with great flaring gas-jets and gaudy play-bills. A hideous
Jew, in the most amazing waistcoat I ever beheld in my life, was
standing at the entrance, smoking a vile cigar. He had greasy ringlets,
and an enormous diamond blazed in the centre of a soiled shirt.']
qText:
I will tell you, Harry, but you mustn t be unsympathetic about it.
After all, it never would have happened if I had not met you. You
filled me with a wild desire to know everything about life. For days
after I met you, something seemed to throb in my veins. As I lounged in
the park, or strolled down Piccadilly, I used to look at every one who
passed me and wonder, with a mad curiosity, what sort of lives they
led. Some of them fascinated me. Others filled me with terror. There
was an exquisite poison in the air. I had a passion for sensations....
Well, one evening about seven o clock, I determined to go out in search
of some adventure. I felt that this grey monstrous London of ours, with
its myriads of people, its sordid sinners, and its splendid sins, as
you once phrased it, must have something in store for me. I fancied a
thousand things. The mere danger gave me a sense of delight. I
remembered what you had said to me on that wonderful evening when we
first dined together, about the search for beauty being the real secret
of life. I don t know what I expected, but I went out and wandered
eastward, soon losing my way in a labyrinth of grimy streets and black
grassless squares. About half-past eight I passed by an absurd little
theatre, with great flaring gas-jets and gaudy play-bills. A hideous
Jew, in the most amazing waistcoat I ever beheld in my life, was
standing at the entrance, smoking a vile cigar. He had greasy ringlets,
and an enormous diamond blazed in the centre of a soiled shirt.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['he said, when he saw me, and he took off his hat with an
air of gorgeous servility. There was something about him, Harry, that
amused me. He was such a monster. You will laugh at me, I know, but I
really went in and paid a whole guinea for the stage-box. To the
present day I can t make out why I did so; and yet if I hadn t my dear
Harry, if I hadn t I should have missed the greatest romance of my
life. I see you are laughing. It is horrid of you!']
qText:
he said, when he saw me, and he took off his hat with an
air of gorgeous servility. There was something about him, Harry, that
amused me. He was such a monster. You will laugh at me, I know, but I
really went in and paid a whole guinea for the stage-box. To the
present day I can t make out why I did so; and yet if I hadn t my dear
Harry, if I hadn t I should have missed the greatest romance of my
life. I see you are laughing. It is horrid of you!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['I am not laughing, Dorian; at least I am not laughing at you. But you
should not say the greatest romance of your life. You should say the
first romance of your life. You will always be loved, and you will
always be in love with love. A _grande passion_ is the privilege of
people who have nothing to do. That is the one use of the idle classes
of a country. Don t be afraid. There are exquisite things in store for
you. This is merely the beginning.']
qText:
I am not laughing, Dorian; at least I am not laughing at you. But you
should not say the greatest romance of your life. You should say the
first romance of your life. You will always be loved, and you will
always be in love with love. A _grande passion_ is the privilege of
people who have nothing to do. That is the one use of the idle classes
of a country. Don t be afraid. There are exquisite things in store for
you. This is merely the beginning.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Do you think my nature so shallow?']
qText: Do you think my nature so shallow?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['No; I think your nature so deep.']
qText: No; I think your nature so deep.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['How do you mean?']
qText: How do you mean?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['My dear boy, the people who love only once in their lives are really
the shallow people. What they call their loyalty, and their fidelity, I
call either the lethargy of custom or their lack of imagination.
Faithfulness is to the emotional life what consistency is to the life
of the intellect simply a confession of failure. Faithfulness! I must
analyse it some day. The passion for property is in it. There are many
things that we would throw away if we were not afraid that others might
pick them up. But I don t want to interrupt you. Go on with your
story.']
qText:
My dear boy, the people who love only once in their lives are really
the shallow people. What they call their loyalty, and their fidelity, I
call either the lethargy of custom or their lack of imagination.
Faithfulness is to the emotional life what consistency is to the life
of the intellect simply a confession of failure. Faithfulness! I must
analyse it some day. The passion for property is in it. There are many
things that we would throw away if we were not afraid that others might
pick them up. But I don t want to interrupt you. Go on with your
story.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Well, I found myself seated in a horrid little private box, with a
vulgar drop-scene staring me in the face. I looked out from behind the
curtain and surveyed the house. It was a tawdry affair, all Cupids and
cornucopias, like a third-rate wedding-cake. The gallery and pit were
fairly full, but the two rows of dingy stalls were quite empty, and
there was hardly a person in what I suppose they called the
dress-circle. Women went about with oranges and ginger-beer, and there
was a terrible consumption of nuts going on.']
qText:
Well, I found myself seated in a horrid little private box, with a
vulgar drop-scene staring me in the face. I looked out from behind the
curtain and surveyed the house. It was a tawdry affair, all Cupids and
cornucopias, like a third-rate wedding-cake. The gallery and pit were
fairly full, but the two rows of dingy stalls were quite empty, and
there was hardly a person in what I suppose they called the
dress-circle. Women went about with oranges and ginger-beer, and there
was a terrible consumption of nuts going on.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It must have been just like the palmy days of the British drama.']
qText: It must have been just like the palmy days of the British drama.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Just like, I should fancy, and very depressing. I began to wonder what\non earth I should do when I caught sight of the play-bill. What do you\nthink the play was, Harry?']
qText:
Just like, I should fancy, and very depressing. I began to wonder what
on earth I should do when I caught sight of the play-bill. What do you
think the play was, Harry?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['I should think  The Idiot Boy , or  Dumb but Innocent . Our fathers
used to like that sort of piece, I believe. The longer I live, Dorian,
the more keenly I feel that whatever was good enough for our fathers is
not good enough for us. In art, as in politics, _les grandp res ont
toujours tort_.']
qText:
I should think  The Idiot Boy , or  Dumb but Innocent . Our fathers
used to like that sort of piece, I believe. The longer I live, Dorian,
the more keenly I feel that whatever was good enough for our fathers is
not good enough for us. In art, as in politics, _les grandp res ont
toujours tort_.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['This play was good enough for us, Harry. It was Romeo and Juliet. I
must admit that I was rather annoyed at the idea of seeing Shakespeare
done in such a wretched hole of a place. Still, I felt interested, in a
sort of way. At any rate, I determined to wait for the first act. There
was a dreadful orchestra, presided over by a young Hebrew who sat at a
cracked piano, that nearly drove me away, but at last the drop-scene
was drawn up and the play began. Romeo was a stout elderly gentleman,
with corked eyebrows, a husky tragedy voice, and a figure like a
beer-barrel. Mercutio was almost as bad. He was played by the
low-comedian, who had introduced gags of his own and was on most
friendly terms with the pit. They were both as grotesque as the
scenery, and that looked as if it had come out of a country-booth. But
Juliet! Harry, imagine a girl, hardly seventeen years of age, with a
little, flowerlike face, a small Greek head with plaited coils of
dark-brown hair, eyes that were violet wells of passion, lips that were
like the petals of a rose. She was the loveliest thing I had ever seen
in my life. You said to me once that pathos left you unmoved, but that
beauty, mere beauty, could fill your eyes with tears. I tell you,
Harry, I could hardly see this girl for the mist of tears that came
across me. And her voice I never heard such a voice. It was very low at
first, with deep mellow notes that seemed to fall singly upon one s
ear. Then it became a little louder, and sounded like a flute or a
distant hautboy. In the garden-scene it had all the tremulous ecstasy
that one hears just before dawn when nightingales are singing. There
were moments, later on, when it had the wild passion of violins. You
know how a voice can stir one. Your voice and the voice of Sibyl Vane
are two things that I shall never forget. When I close my eyes, I hear
them, and each of them says something different. I don t know which to
follow. Why should I not love her? Harry, I do love her. She is
everything to me in life. Night after night I go to see her play. One
evening she is Rosalind, and the next evening she is Imogen. I have
seen her die in the gloom of an Italian tomb, sucking the poison from
her lover s lips. I have watched her wandering through the forest of
Arden, disguised as a pretty boy in hose and doublet and dainty cap.
She has been mad, and has come into the presence of a guilty king, and
given him rue to wear and bitter herbs to taste of. She has been
innocent, and the black hands of jealousy have crushed her reedlike
throat. I have seen her in every age and in every costume. Ordinary
women never appeal to one s imagination. They are limited to their
century. No glamour ever transfigures them. One knows their minds as
easily as one knows their bonnets. One can always find them. There is
no mystery in any of them. They ride in the park in the morning and
chatter at tea-parties in the afternoon. They have their stereotyped
smile and their fashionable manner. They are quite obvious. But an
actress! How different an actress is! Harry! why didn t you tell me
that the only thing worth loving is an actress?']
qText:
This play was good enough for us, Harry. It was Romeo and Juliet. I
must admit that I was rather annoyed at the idea of seeing Shakespeare
done in such a wretched hole of a place. Still, I felt interested, in a
sort of way. At any rate, I determined to wait for the first act. There
was a dreadful orchestra, presided over by a young Hebrew who sat at a
cracked piano, that nearly drove me away, but at last the drop-scene
was drawn up and the play began. Romeo was a stout elderly gentleman,
with corked eyebrows, a husky tragedy voice, and a figure like a
beer-barrel. Mercutio was almost as bad. He was played by the
low-comedian, who had introduced gags of his own and was on most
friendly terms with the pit. They were both as grotesque as the
scenery, and that looked as if it had come out of a country-booth. But
Juliet! Harry, imagine a girl, hardly seventeen years of age, with a
little, flowerlike face, a small Greek head with plaited coils of
dark-brown hair, eyes that were violet wells of passion, lips that were
like the petals of a rose. She was the loveliest thing I had ever seen
in my life. You said to me once that pathos left you unmoved, but that
beauty, mere beauty, could fill your eyes with tears. I tell you,
Harry, I could hardly see this girl for the mist of tears that came
across me. And her voice I never heard such a voice. It was very low at
first, with deep mellow notes that seemed to fall singly upon one s
ear. Then it became a little louder, and sounded like a flute or a
distant hautboy. In the garden-scene it had all the tremulous ecstasy
that one hears just before dawn when nightingales are singing. There
were moments, later on, when it had the wild passion of violins. You
know how a voice can stir one. Your voice and the voice of Sibyl Vane
are two things that I shall never forget. When I close my eyes, I hear
them, and each of them says something different. I don t know which to
follow. Why should I not love her? Harry, I do love her. She is
everything to me in life. Night after night I go to see her play. One
evening she is Rosalind, and the next evening she is Imogen. I have
seen her die in the gloom of an Italian tomb, sucking the poison from
her lover s lips. I have watched her wandering through the forest of
Arden, disguised as a pretty boy in hose and doublet and dainty cap.
She has been mad, and has come into the presence of a guilty king, and
given him rue to wear and bitter herbs to taste of. She has been
innocent, and the black hands of jealousy have crushed her reedlike
throat. I have seen her in every age and in every costume. Ordinary
women never appeal to one s imagination. They are limited to their
century. No glamour ever transfigures them. One knows their minds as
easily as one knows their bonnets. One can always find them. There is
no mystery in any of them. They ride in the park in the morning and
chatter at tea-parties in the afternoon. They have their stereotyped
smile and their fashionable manner. They are quite obvious. But an
actress! How different an actress is! Harry! why didn t you tell me
that the only thing worth loving is an actress?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Yes, Harry, I believe that is true. I cannot help telling you things.\nYou have a curious influence over me. If I ever did a crime, I would\ncome and confess it to you. You would understand me.']
