there. Yes: you led them there, and yet you can smile, as you are
smiling now. And there is worse behind. I know you and Harry are
inseparable. Surely for that reason, if for none other, you should not
have made his sister s name a by-word.
speaker: Basil Hallward
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray']], [['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr: ['Take care, Basil. You go too far.']
qText: Take care, Basil. You go too far.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['I must speak, and you must listen. You shall listen. When you met Lady
Gwendolen, not a breath of scandal had ever touched her. Is there a
single decent woman in London now who would drive with her in the park?
Why, even her children are not allowed to live with her. Then there are
other stories stories that you have been seen creeping at dawn out of
dreadful houses and slinking in disguise into the foulest dens in
London. Are they true? Can they be true? When I first heard them, I
laughed. I hear them now, and they make me shudder. What about your
country-house and the life that is led there? Dorian, you don t know
what is said about you. I won t tell you that I don t want to preach to
you. I remember Harry saying once that every man who turned himself
into an amateur curate for the moment always began by saying that, and
then proceeded to break his word. I do want to preach to you. I want
you to lead such a life as will make the world respect you. I want you
to have a clean name and a fair record. I want you to get rid of the
dreadful people you associate with. Don t shrug your shoulders like
that. Don t be so indifferent. You have a wonderful influence. Let it
be for good, not for evil. They say that you corrupt every one with
whom you become intimate, and that it is quite sufficient for you to
enter a house for shame of some kind to follow after. I don t know
whether it is so or not. How should I know? But it is said of you. I am
told things that it seems impossible to doubt. Lord Gloucester was one
of my greatest friends at Oxford. He showed me a letter that his wife
had written to him when she was dying alone in her villa at Mentone.
Your name was implicated in the most terrible confession I ever read. I
told him that it was absurd that I knew you thoroughly and that you
were incapable of anything of the kind. Know you? I wonder do I know
you? Before I could answer that, I should have to see your soul.']
qText:
I must speak, and you must listen. You shall listen. When you met Lady
Gwendolen, not a breath of scandal had ever touched her. Is there a
single decent woman in London now who would drive with her in the park?
Why, even her children are not allowed to live with her. Then there are
other stories stories that you have been seen creeping at dawn out of
dreadful houses and slinking in disguise into the foulest dens in
London. Are they true? Can they be true? When I first heard them, I
laughed. I hear them now, and they make me shudder. What about your
country-house and the life that is led there? Dorian, you don t know
what is said about you. I won t tell you that I don t want to preach to
you. I remember Harry saying once that every man who turned himself
into an amateur curate for the moment always began by saying that, and
then proceeded to break his word. I do want to preach to you. I want
you to lead such a life as will make the world respect you. I want you
to have a clean name and a fair record. I want you to get rid of the
dreadful people you associate with. Don t shrug your shoulders like
that. Don t be so indifferent. You have a wonderful influence. Let it
be for good, not for evil. They say that you corrupt every one with
whom you become intimate, and that it is quite sufficient for you to
enter a house for shame of some kind to follow after. I don t know
whether it is so or not. How should I know? But it is said of you. I am
told things that it seems impossible to doubt. Lord Gloucester was one
of my greatest friends at Oxford. He showed me a letter that his wife
had written to him when she was dying alone in her villa at Mentone.
Your name was implicated in the most terrible confession I ever read. I
told him that it was absurd that I knew you thoroughly and that you
were incapable of anything of the kind. Know you? I wonder do I know
you? Before I could answer that, I should have to see your soul.
speaker: Basil Hallward
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['To see my soul!']
qText: To see my soul!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'to see your soul. But only God can do that.']
qText: Yes, to see your soul. But only God can do that.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr:
['You
shall see it yourself, to-night!', 'Come: it is your own handiwork. Why shouldn t you look at it?
You can tell the world all about it afterwards, if you choose. Nobody
would believe you. If they did believe you, they would like me all the
better for it. I know the age better than you do, though you will prate
about it so tediously. Come, I tell you. You have chattered enough
about corruption. Now you shall look on it face to face.']
qText:
You
shall see it yourself, to-night! Come: it is your own handiwork. Why shouldn t you look at it?
You can tell the world all about it afterwards, if you choose. Nobody
would believe you. If they did believe you, they would like me all the
better for it. I know the age better than you do, though you will prate
about it so tediously. Come, I tell you. You have chattered enough
about corruption. Now you shall look on it face to face.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Basil Hallward']], [['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward']]]

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'I shall show you my soul. You shall see the thing that\nyou fancy only God can see.']
qText:
Yes, I shall show you my soul. You shall see the thing that
you fancy only God can see.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['This is blasphemy, Dorian!', 'You must\nnot say things like that. They are horrible, and they don t mean\nanything.']
qText:
This is blasphemy, Dorian! You must
not say things like that. They are horrible, and they don t mean
anything.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['You think so?']
qText: You think so?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I know so. As for what I said to you to-night, I said it for your\ngood. You know I have been always a stanch friend to you.']
qText:
I know so. As for what I said to you to-night, I said it for your
good. You know I have been always a stanch friend to you.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Don t touch me. Finish what you have to say.']
qText: Don t touch me. Finish what you have to say.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I am waiting, Basil,']
qText: I am waiting, Basil,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['What I have to say is this,', 'You must give
me some answer to these horrible charges that are made against you. If
you tell me that they are absolutely untrue from beginning to end, I
shall believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them! Can t you see what I
am going through? My God! don t tell me that you are bad, and corrupt,
and shameful.']
qText:
What I have to say is this, You must give
me some answer to these horrible charges that are made against you. If
you tell me that they are absolutely untrue from beginning to end, I
shall believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them! Can t you see what I
am going through? My God! don t tell me that you are bad, and corrupt,
and shameful.
speaker: Basil Hallward
menEnts: [[], [['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr:
['Come
upstairs, Basil,', 'I keep a diary of my life from day
to day, and it never leaves the room in which it is written. I shall
show it to you if you come with me.']
qText:
Come
upstairs, Basil, I keep a diary of my life from day
to day, and it never leaves the room in which it is written. I shall
show it to you if you come with me.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I shall come with you, Dorian, if you wish it. I see I have missed my\ntrain. That makes no matter. I can go to-morrow. But don t ask me to\nread anything to-night. All I want is a plain answer to my question.']
qText:
I shall come with you, Dorian, if you wish it. I see I have missed my
train. That makes no matter. I can go to-morrow. But don t ask me to
read anything to-night. All I want is a plain answer to my question.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['That shall be given to you upstairs. I could not give it here. You\nwill not have to read long.']
qText:
That shall be given to you upstairs. I could not give it here. You
will not have to read long.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You insist on\nknowing, Basil?']
qText:
You insist on
knowing, Basil?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qText: Yes.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I am delighted,']
qText: I am delighted,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You are the one man in the world who is entitled to know\neverything about me. You have had more to do with my life than you\nthink']
qText:
You are the one man in the world who is entitled to know
everything about me. You have had more to do with my life than you
think
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Shut the door behind you,']
qText: Shut the door behind you,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['So you think that it is only God who sees the soul, Basil? Draw that\ncurtain back, and you will see mine.']
qText:
So you think that it is only God who sees the soul, Basil? Draw that
curtain back, and you will see mine.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You are mad, Dorian, or\nplaying a part,']
qText:
You are mad, Dorian, or
playing a part,
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['You won t? Then I must do it myself,']
qText: You won t? Then I must do it myself,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['What does this mean?']
qText: What does this mean?
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr:
['Years ago, when I was a boy,', 'you met me, flattered me, and taught me to be vain of my
good looks. One day you introduced me to a friend of yours, who
explained to me the wonder of youth, and you finished a portrait of me
that revealed to me the wonder of beauty. In a mad moment that, even
now, I don t know whether I regret or not, I made a wish, perhaps you
would call it a prayer....']
qText:
Years ago, when I was a boy, you met me, flattered me, and taught me to be vain of my
good looks. One day you introduced me to a friend of yours, who
explained to me the wonder of youth, and you finished a portrait of me
that revealed to me the wonder of beauty. In a mad moment that, even
now, I don t know whether I regret or not, I made a wish, perhaps you
would call it a prayer....
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['I remember it! Oh, how well I remember it! No! the thing is
impossible. The room is damp. Mildew has got into the canvas. The
paints I used had some wretched mineral poison in them. I tell you the
thing is impossible.']
qText:
I remember it! Oh, how well I remember it! No! the thing is
impossible. The room is damp. Mildew has got into the canvas. The
paints I used had some wretched mineral poison in them. I tell you the
thing is impossible.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Ah, what is impossible?']
qText: Ah, what is impossible?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You told me you had destroyed it.']
qText: You told me you had destroyed it.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I was wrong. It has destroyed me.']
qText: I was wrong. It has destroyed me.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I don t believe it is my picture.']
qText: I don t believe it is my picture.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Can t you see your ideal in it?']
qText: Can t you see your ideal in it?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['My ideal, as you call it...']
qText: My ideal, as you call it...
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['As you called it.']
qText: As you called it.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['There was nothing evil in it, nothing shameful. You were to me such an\nideal as I shall never meet again. This is the face of a satyr.']
qText:
There was nothing evil in it, nothing shameful. You were to me such an
ideal as I shall never meet again. This is the face of a satyr.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['It is the face of my soul.']
qText: It is the face of my soul.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Christ! what a thing I must have worshipped! It has the eyes of a\ndevil.']
qText:
Christ! what a thing I must have worshipped! It has the eyes of a
devil.
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Each of us has heaven and hell in him, Basil,']
qText: Each of us has heaven and hell in him, Basil,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['My God! If it
is true,', 'and this is what you have done with your life,
why, you must be worse even than those who talk against you fancy you
to be!']
qText:
My God! If it
is true, and this is what you have done with your life,
why, you must be worse even than those who talk against you fancy you
to be!
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['Good God, Dorian, what a lesson! What an awful lesson!']
qText: Good God, Dorian, what a lesson! What an awful lesson!
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr:
['Pray,
Dorian, pray,', 'What is it that one was taught to say in
one s boyhood?', 'Let us say that together. The prayer of your
pride has been answered. The prayer of your repentance will be answered
also. I worshipped you too much. I am punished for it. You worshipped
yourself too much. We are both punished.']
qText:
Pray,
Dorian, pray, What is it that one was taught to say in
one s boyhood? Let us say that together. The prayer of your
pride has been answered. The prayer of your repentance will be answered
also. I worshipped you too much. I am punished for it. You worshipped
yourself too much. We are both punished.
speaker: Basil Hallward
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray']], [], [['Basil Hallward', 'Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Basil Hallward']]]

qTextArr: ['It is too late, Basil,']
qText: It is too late, Basil,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It is never too late, Dorian. Let us kneel down and try if we cannot\nremember a prayer. Isn t there a verse somewhere,  Though your sins be\nas scarlet, yet I will make them as white as snow ?']
qText:
It is never too late, Dorian. Let us kneel down and try if we cannot
remember a prayer. Isn t there a verse somewhere,  Though your sins be
as scarlet, yet I will make them as white as snow ?
speaker: Basil Hallward
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Basil Hallward'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Basil Hallward'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['Those words mean nothing to me now.']
qText: Those words mean nothing to me now.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Hush! Don t say that. You have done enough evil in your life. My God!\nDon t you see that accursed thing leering at us?']
qText:
Hush! Don t say that. You have done enough evil in your life. My God!
Don t you see that accursed thing leering at us?
speaker: Basil Hallward

qTextArr: ['I am sorry to have had to wake you up, Francis,', 'but I had forgotten my latch-key. What time is it?']
qText: I am sorry to have had to wake you up, Francis, but I had forgotten my latch-key. What time is it?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Ten minutes past two, sir,']
qText: Ten minutes past two, sir,
speaker: Francis

qTextArr: ['Ten minutes past two? How horribly late! You must wake me at nine\nto-morrow. I have some work to do.']
qText:
Ten minutes past two? How horribly late! You must wake me at nine
to-morrow. I have some work to do.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['All right, sir.']
qText: All right, sir.
speaker: Francis

qTextArr: ['Did any one call this evening?']
qText: Did any one call this evening?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Mr. Hallward, sir. He stayed here till eleven, and then he went away\nto catch his train.']
qText:
Mr. Hallward, sir. He stayed here till eleven, and then he went away
to catch his train.
speaker: Francis

qTextArr: ['Oh! I am sorry I didn t see him. Did he leave any message?']
qText: Oh! I am sorry I didn t see him. Did he leave any message?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['No, sir, except that he would write to you from Paris, if he did not\nfind you at the club.']
qText:
No, sir, except that he would write to you from Paris, if he did not
find you at the club.
speaker: Francis

qTextArr: ['That will do, Francis. Don t forget to call me at nine to-morrow.']
qText: That will do, Francis. Don t forget to call me at nine to-morrow.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['No, sir.']
qText: No, sir.
speaker: Francis

qTextArr: ['Take this round to 152, Hertford Street, Francis, and if Mr. Campbell\nis out of town, get his address.']
qText:
Take this round to 152, Hertford Street, Francis, and if Mr. Campbell
is out of town, get his address.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Mr. Campbell, sir,']
qText: Mr. Campbell, sir,
speaker: Francis

qTextArr: ['Ask him to come in at once, Francis.']
qText: Ask him to come in at once, Francis.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Alan! This is kind of you. I thank you for coming.']
qText: Alan! This is kind of you. I thank you for coming.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I had intended never to enter your house again, Gray. But you said it\nwas a matter of life and death.']
qText:
I had intended never to enter your house again, Gray. But you said it
was a matter of life and death.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['Yes: it is a matter of life and death, Alan, and to more than one\nperson. Sit down.']
qText:
Yes: it is a matter of life and death, Alan, and to more than one
person. Sit down.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Alan, in a locked room at the top of this house, a room
to which nobody but myself has access, a dead man is seated at a table.
He has been dead ten hours now. Don t stir, and don t look at me like
that. Who the man is, why he died, how he died, are matters that do not
concern you. What you have to do is this']
qText:
Alan, in a locked room at the top of this house, a room
to which nobody but myself has access, a dead man is seated at a table.
He has been dead ten hours now. Don t stir, and don t look at me like
that. Who the man is, why he died, how he died, are matters that do not
concern you. What you have to do is this
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Alan Campbell'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell']]]

qTextArr:
['Stop, Gray. I don t want to know anything further. Whether what you
have told me is true or not true doesn t concern me. I entirely decline
to be mixed up in your life. Keep your horrible secrets to yourself.
They don t interest me any more.']
qText:
Stop, Gray. I don t want to know anything further. Whether what you
have told me is true or not true doesn t concern me. I entirely decline
to be mixed up in your life. Keep your horrible secrets to yourself.
They don t interest me any more.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr:
['Alan, they will have to interest you. This one will have to interest
you. I am awfully sorry for you, Alan. But I can t help myself. You are
the one man who is able to save me. I am forced to bring you into the
matter. I have no option. Alan, you are scientific. You know about
chemistry and things of that kind. You have made experiments. What you
have got to do is to destroy the thing that is upstairs to destroy it
so that not a vestige of it will be left. Nobody saw this person come
into the house. Indeed, at the present moment he is supposed to be in
Paris. He will not be missed for months. When he is missed, there must
be no trace of him found here. You, Alan, you must change him, and
everything that belongs to him, into a handful of ashes that I may
scatter in the air.']
qText:
Alan, they will have to interest you. This one will have to interest
you. I am awfully sorry for you, Alan. But I can t help myself. You are
the one man who is able to save me. I am forced to bring you into the
matter. I have no option. Alan, you are scientific. You know about
chemistry and things of that kind. You have made experiments. What you
have got to do is to destroy the thing that is upstairs to destroy it
so that not a vestige of it will be left. Nobody saw this person come
into the house. Indeed, at the present moment he is supposed to be in
Paris. He will not be missed for months. When he is missed, there must
be no trace of him found here. You, Alan, you must change him, and
everything that belongs to him, into a handful of ashes that I may
scatter in the air.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward']]]

qTextArr: ['You are mad, Dorian.']
qText: You are mad, Dorian.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['Ah! I was waiting for you to call me Dorian.']
qText: Ah! I was waiting for you to call me Dorian.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['You are mad, I tell you mad to imagine that I would raise a finger to
help you, mad to make this monstrous confession. I will have nothing to
do with this matter, whatever it is. Do you think I am going to peril
my reputation for you? What is it to me what devil s work you are up
to?']
qText:
You are mad, I tell you mad to imagine that I would raise a finger to
help you, mad to make this monstrous confession. I will have nothing to
do with this matter, whatever it is. Do you think I am going to peril
my reputation for you? What is it to me what devil s work you are up
to?
speaker: Alan Campbell
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['It was suicide, Alan.']
qText: It was suicide, Alan.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I am glad of that. But who drove him to it? You, I should fancy.']
qText: I am glad of that. But who drove him to it? You, I should fancy.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['Do you still refuse to do this for me?']
qText: Do you still refuse to do this for me?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Of course I refuse. I will have absolutely nothing to do with it. I
don t care what shame comes on you. You deserve it all. I should not be
sorry to see you disgraced, publicly disgraced. How dare you ask me, of
all men in the world, to mix myself up in this horror? I should have
thought you knew more about people s characters. Your friend Lord Henry
Wotton can t have taught you much about psychology, whatever else he
has taught you. Nothing will induce me to stir a step to help you. You
have come to the wrong man. Go to some of your friends. Don t come to
me.']
qText:
Of course I refuse. I will have absolutely nothing to do with it. I
don t care what shame comes on you. You deserve it all. I should not be
sorry to see you disgraced, publicly disgraced. How dare you ask me, of
all men in the world, to mix myself up in this horror? I should have
thought you knew more about people s characters. Your friend Lord Henry
Wotton can t have taught you much about psychology, whatever else he
has taught you. Nothing will induce me to stir a step to help you. You
have come to the wrong man. Go to some of your friends. Don t come to
me.
speaker: Alan Campbell
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr:
['Alan, it was murder. I killed him. You don t know what he had made me
suffer. Whatever my life is, he had more to do with the making or the
marring of it than poor Harry has had. He may not have intended it, the
result was the same.']
qText:
Alan, it was murder. I killed him. You don t know what he had made me
suffer. Whatever my life is, he had more to do with the making or the
marring of it than poor Harry has had. He may not have intended it, the
result was the same.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Alan Campbell'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Basil Hallward']]]

qTextArr:
['Murder! Good God, Dorian, is that what you have come to? I shall not
inform upon you. It is not my business. Besides, without my stirring in
the matter, you are certain to be arrested. Nobody ever commits a crime
without doing something stupid. But I will have nothing to do with it.']
qText:
Murder! Good God, Dorian, is that what you have come to? I shall not
inform upon you. It is not my business. Besides, without my stirring in
the matter, you are certain to be arrested. Nobody ever commits a crime
without doing something stupid. But I will have nothing to do with it.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr:
['You must have something to do with it. Wait, wait a moment; listen to
me. Only listen, Alan. All I ask of you is to perform a certain
scientific experiment. You go to hospitals and dead-houses, and the
horrors that you do there don t affect you. If in some hideous
dissecting-room or fetid laboratory you found this man lying on a
leaden table with red gutters scooped out in it for the blood to flow
through, you would simply look upon him as an admirable subject. You
would not turn a hair. You would not believe that you were doing
anything wrong. On the contrary, you would probably feel that you were
benefiting the human race, or increasing the sum of knowledge in the
world, or gratifying intellectual curiosity, or something of that kind.
What I want you to do is merely what you have often done before.
Indeed, to destroy a body must be far less horrible than what you are
accustomed to work at. And, remember, it is the only piece of evidence
against me. If it is discovered, I am lost; and it is sure to be
discovered unless you help me.']
qText:
You must have something to do with it. Wait, wait a moment; listen to
me. Only listen, Alan. All I ask of you is to perform a certain
scientific experiment. You go to hospitals and dead-houses, and the
horrors that you do there don t affect you. If in some hideous
dissecting-room or fetid laboratory you found this man lying on a
leaden table with red gutters scooped out in it for the blood to flow
through, you would simply look upon him as an admirable subject. You
would not turn a hair. You would not believe that you were doing
anything wrong. On the contrary, you would probably feel that you were
benefiting the human race, or increasing the sum of knowledge in the
world, or gratifying intellectual curiosity, or something of that kind.
What I want you to do is merely what you have often done before.
Indeed, to destroy a body must be far less horrible than what you are
accustomed to work at. And, remember, it is the only piece of evidence
against me. If it is discovered, I am lost; and it is sure to be
discovered unless you help me.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell']]]

qTextArr: ['I have no desire to help you. You forget that. I am simply indifferent\nto the whole thing. It has nothing to do with me.']
qText:
I have no desire to help you. You forget that. I am simply indifferent
to the whole thing. It has nothing to do with me.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr:
['Alan, I entreat you. Think of the position I am in. Just before you
came I almost fainted with terror. You may know terror yourself some
day. No! don t think of that. Look at the matter purely from the
scientific point of view. You don t inquire where the dead things on
which you experiment come from. Don t inquire now. I have told you too
much as it is. But I beg of you to do this. We were friends once,
Alan.']
qText:
Alan, I entreat you. Think of the position I am in. Just before you
came I almost fainted with terror. You may know terror yourself some
day. No! don t think of that. Look at the matter purely from the
scientific point of view. You don t inquire where the dead things on
which you experiment come from. Don t inquire now. I have told you too
much as it is. But I beg of you to do this. We were friends once,
Alan.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell']]]

qTextArr: ['Don t speak about those days, Dorian they are dead.']
qText: Don t speak about those days, Dorian they are dead.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr:
['The dead linger sometimes. The man upstairs will not go away. He is
sitting at the table with bowed head and outstretched arms. Alan! Alan!
If you don t come to my assistance, I am ruined. Why, they will hang
me, Alan! Don t you understand? They will hang me for what I have
done.']
qText:
The dead linger sometimes. The man upstairs will not go away. He is
sitting at the table with bowed head and outstretched arms. Alan! Alan!
If you don t come to my assistance, I am ruined. Why, they will hang
me, Alan! Don t you understand? They will hang me for what I have
done.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell']]]

qTextArr: ['There is no good in prolonging this scene. I absolutely refuse to do\nanything in the matter. It is insane of you to ask me.']
qText:
There is no good in prolonging this scene. I absolutely refuse to do
anything in the matter. It is insane of you to ask me.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['You refuse?']
qText: You refuse?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qText: Yes.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['I entreat you, Alan.']
qText: I entreat you, Alan.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It is useless.']
qText: It is useless.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr:
['I am so sorry for you, Alan,', 'but you leave me no
alternative. I have a letter written already. Here it is. You see the
address. If you don t help me, I must send it. If you don t help me, I
will send it. You know what the result will be. But you are going to
help me. It is impossible for you to refuse now. I tried to spare you.
You will do me the justice to admit that. You were stern, harsh,
offensive. You treated me as no man has ever dared to treat me no
living man, at any rate. I bore it all. Now it is for me to dictate
terms.']
qText:
I am so sorry for you, Alan, but you leave me no
alternative. I have a letter written already. Here it is. You see the
address. If you don t help me, I must send it. If you don t help me, I
will send it. You know what the result will be. But you are going to
help me. It is impossible for you to refuse now. I tried to spare you.
You will do me the justice to admit that. You were stern, harsh,
offensive. You treated me as no man has ever dared to treat me no
living man, at any rate. I bore it all. Now it is for me to dictate
terms.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell']], [['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell'], ['Alan Campbell']]]

qTextArr: ['Yes, it is my turn to dictate terms, Alan. You know what they are. The\nthing is quite simple. Come, don t work yourself into this fever. The\nthing has to be done. Face it, and do it.']
qText:
Yes, it is my turn to dictate terms, Alan. You know what they are. The
thing is quite simple. Come, don t work yourself into this fever. The
thing has to be done. Face it, and do it.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Come, Alan, you must decide at once.']
qText: Come, Alan, you must decide at once.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I cannot do it,']
qText: I cannot do it,
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['You must. You have no choice. Don t delay.']
qText: You must. You have no choice. Don t delay.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Is there a fire in the room upstairs?']
qText: Is there a fire in the room upstairs?
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['Yes, there is a gas-fire with asbestos.']
qText: Yes, there is a gas-fire with asbestos.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I shall have to go home and get some things from the laboratory.']
qText: I shall have to go home and get some things from the laboratory.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['No, Alan, you must not leave the house. Write out on a sheet of\nnotepaper what you want and my servant will take a cab and bring the\nthings back to you.']
qText:
No, Alan, you must not leave the house. Write out on a sheet of
notepaper what you want and my servant will take a cab and bring the
things back to you.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You are infamous, absolutely infamous!']
qText: You are infamous, absolutely infamous!
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['Hush, Alan. You have saved my life,']
qText: Hush, Alan. You have saved my life,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Your life? Good heavens! what a life that is! You have gone from
corruption to corruption, and now you have culminated in crime. In
doing what I am going to do what you force me to do it is not of your
life that I am thinking.']
qText:
Your life? Good heavens! what a life that is! You have gone from
corruption to corruption, and now you have culminated in crime. In
doing what I am going to do what you force me to do it is not of your
life that I am thinking.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['Ah, Alan,', 'I wish you had a thousandth\npart of the pity for me that I have for you.']
qText:
Ah, Alan, I wish you had a thousandth
part of the pity for me that I have for you.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Shall I leave the things here, sir?']
qText: Shall I leave the things here, sir?
speaker: Francis

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'And I am afraid, Francis, that I have another\nerrand for you. What is the name of the man at Richmond who supplies\nSelby with orchids?']
qText:
Yes, And I am afraid, Francis, that I have another
errand for you. What is the name of the man at Richmond who supplies
Selby with orchids?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Harden, sir.']
qText: Harden, sir.
speaker: Francis

qTextArr:
['Yes Harden. You must go down to Richmond at once, see Harden
personally, and tell him to send twice as many orchids as I ordered,
and to have as few white ones as possible. In fact, I don t want any
white ones. It is a lovely day, Francis, and Richmond is a very pretty
place otherwise I wouldn t bother you about it.']
qText:
Yes Harden. You must go down to Richmond at once, see Harden
personally, and tell him to send twice as many orchids as I ordered,
and to have as few white ones as possible. In fact, I don t want any
white ones. It is a lovely day, Francis, and Richmond is a very pretty
place otherwise I wouldn t bother you about it.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['No trouble, sir. At what time shall I be back?']
qText: No trouble, sir. At what time shall I be back?
speaker: Francis

qTextArr: ['How long will your experiment take, Alan?']
qText: How long will your experiment take, Alan?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It will take about five hours,']
qText: It will take about five hours,
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr:
['It will be time enough, then, if you are back at half-past seven,
Francis. Or stay: just leave my things out for dressing. You can have
the evening to yourself. I am not dining at home, so I shall not want
you.']
qText:
It will be time enough, then, if you are back at half-past seven,
Francis. Or stay: just leave my things out for dressing. You can have
the evening to yourself. I am not dining at home, so I shall not want
you.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Thank you, sir,']
qText: Thank you, sir,
speaker: Francis

qTextArr: ['Now, Alan, there is not a moment to be lost. How heavy this chest is!\nI ll take it for you. You bring the other things.']
qText:
Now, Alan, there is not a moment to be lost. How heavy this chest is!
I ll take it for you. You bring the other things.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I don t think I can go in, Alan,']
qText: I don t think I can go in, Alan,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It is nothing to me. I don t require you,']
qText: It is nothing to me. I don t require you,
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['Leave me now,']
qText: Leave me now,
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['I have done what you asked me to do,', 'And now, good-bye. Let us never see each other again.']
qText: I have done what you asked me to do, And now, good-bye. Let us never see each other again.
speaker: Alan Campbell

qTextArr: ['You have saved me from ruin, Alan. I cannot forget that,']
qText: You have saved me from ruin, Alan. I cannot forget that,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['I know, my
dear, I should have fallen madly in love with you,', 'and thrown my bonnet right over the mills for your sake. It is most
fortunate that you were not thought of at the time. As it was, our
bonnets were so unbecoming, and the mills were so occupied in trying to
raise the wind, that I never had even a flirtation with anybody.
However, that was all Narborough s fault. He was dreadfully
short-sighted, and there is no pleasure in taking in a husband who
never sees anything.']
qText:
I know, my
dear, I should have fallen madly in love with you, and thrown my bonnet right over the mills for your sake. It is most
fortunate that you were not thought of at the time. As it was, our
bonnets were so unbecoming, and the mills were so occupied in trying to
raise the wind, that I never had even a flirtation with anybody.
However, that was all Narborough s fault. He was dreadfully
short-sighted, and there is no pleasure in taking in a husband who
never sees anything.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr:
['I think it
is most unkind of her, my dear,', 'Of course I go and
stay with them every summer after I come from Homburg, but then an old
woman like me must have fresh air sometimes, and besides, I really wake
them up. You don t know what an existence they lead down there. It is
pure unadulterated country life. They get up early, because they have
so much to do, and go to bed early, because they have so little to
think about. There has not been a scandal in the neighbourhood since
the time of Queen Elizabeth, and consequently they all fall asleep
after dinner. You shan t sit next either of them. You shall sit by me
and amuse me.']
qText:
I think it
is most unkind of her, my dear, Of course I go and
stay with them every summer after I come from Homburg, but then an old
woman like me must have fresh air sometimes, and besides, I really wake
them up. You don t know what an existence they lead down there. It is
pure unadulterated country life. They get up early, because they have
so much to do, and go to bed early, because they have so little to
think about. There has not been a scandal in the neighbourhood since
the time of Queen Elizabeth, and consequently they all fall asleep
after dinner. You shan t sit next either of them. You shall sit by me
and amuse me.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['How horrid of Henry Wotton to be\nso late! I sent round to him this morning on chance and he promised\nfaithfully not to disappoint me.']
qText:
How horrid of Henry Wotton to be
so late! I sent round to him this morning on chance and he promised
faithfully not to disappoint me.
speaker: Lady Narborough
refExp: Lady Narborough looking at the great ormolu gilt clock that sprawled in gaudy curves on the mauvedraped mantelshelf exclaimed

qTextArr: ['an\ninsult to poor Adolphe, who invented the _menu_ specially for you,']
qText:
an
insult to poor Adolphe, who invented the _menu_ specially for you,
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['Dorian,', 'what is the matter with you to-night? You are quite out\nof sorts.']
qText:
Dorian, what is the matter with you to-night? You are quite out
of sorts.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I believe he is in love,', 'and that he is\nafraid to tell me for fear I should be jealous. He is quite right. I\ncertainly should.']
qText:
I believe he is in love, and that he is
afraid to tell me for fear I should be jealous. He is quite right. I
certainly should.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['Dear Lady Narborough,', 'I have not been in\nlove for a whole week not, in fact, since Madame de Ferrol left town.']
qText:
Dear Lady Narborough, I have not been in
love for a whole week not, in fact, since Madame de Ferrol left town.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['How you men can fall in love with that woman!', 'I really cannot understand it.']
qText: How you men can fall in love with that woman! I really cannot understand it.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['It is simply because she remembers you when you were a little girl,\nLady Narborough,', 'She is the one link between us and\nyour short frocks.']
qText:
It is simply because she remembers you when you were a little girl,
Lady Narborough, She is the one link between us and
your short frocks.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['She does not remember my short frocks at all, Lord Henry. But I\nremember her very well at Vienna thirty years ago, and how _d collet e_\nshe was then.']
qText:
She does not remember my short frocks at all, Lord Henry. But I
remember her very well at Vienna thirty years ago, and how _d collet e_
she was then.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr:
['She is still _d collet e_,', 'and when she is in a very smart gown she looks like an
_ dition de luxe_ of a bad French novel. She is really wonderful, and
full of surprises. Her capacity for family affection is extraordinary.
When her third husband died, her hair turned quite gold from grief.']
qText:
She is still _d collet e_, and when she is in a very smart gown she looks like an
_ dition de luxe_ of a bad French novel. She is really wonderful, and
full of surprises. Her capacity for family affection is extraordinary.
When her third husband died, her hair turned quite gold from grief.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['How can you, Harry!']
qText: How can you, Harry!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It is a most romantic explanation,', 'But her\nthird husband, Lord Henry! You don t mean to say Ferrol is the fourth?']
qText:
It is a most romantic explanation, But her
third husband, Lord Henry! You don t mean to say Ferrol is the fourth?
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['Certainly, Lady Narborough.']
qText: Certainly, Lady Narborough.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I don t believe a word of it.']
qText: I don t believe a word of it.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['Well, ask Mr. Gray. He is one of her most intimate friends.']
qText: Well, ask Mr. Gray. He is one of her most intimate friends.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Is it true, Mr. Gray?']
qText: Is it true, Mr. Gray?
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr:
['She assures me so, Lady Narborough,', 'I asked her
whether, like Marguerite de Navarre, she had their hearts embalmed and
hung at her girdle. She told me she didn t, because none of them had
had any hearts at all.']
qText:
She assures me so, Lady Narborough, I asked her
whether, like Marguerite de Navarre, she had their hearts embalmed and
hung at her girdle. She told me she didn t, because none of them had
had any hearts at all.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Four husbands! Upon my word that is _trop de z le_.']
qText: Four husbands! Upon my word that is _trop de z le_.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['_Trop d audace_, I tell her,']
qText: _Trop d audace_, I tell her,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Oh! she is audacious enough for anything, my dear. And what is Ferrol\nlike? I don t know him.']
qText:
Oh! she is audacious enough for anything, my dear. And what is Ferrol
like? I don t know him.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['The husbands of very beautiful women belong to the criminal classes,']
qText: The husbands of very beautiful women belong to the criminal classes,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Lord Henry, I am not at all\nsurprised that the world says that you are extremely wicked.']
qText:
Lord Henry, I am not at all
surprised that the world says that you are extremely wicked.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['But what world says that?', 'It can only be the next world. This world and I are on excellent\nterms.']
qText:
But what world says that? It can only be the next world. This world and I are on excellent
terms.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Everybody I know says you are very wicked,']
qText: Everybody I know says you are very wicked,
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr:
['It is perfectly
monstrous,', 'the way people go about nowadays saying
things against one behind one s back that are absolutely and entirely
true.']
qText:
It is perfectly
monstrous, the way people go about nowadays saying
things against one behind one s back that are absolutely and entirely
true.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Isn t he incorrigible?']
qText: Isn t he incorrigible?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I hope so,', 'But really, if you all\nworship Madame de Ferrol in this ridiculous way, I shall have to marry\nagain so as to be in the fashion.']
qText:
I hope so, But really, if you all
worship Madame de Ferrol in this ridiculous way, I shall have to marry
again so as to be in the fashion.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['You will never marry again, Lady Narborough,', 'You were far too happy. When a woman marries again, it is because she\ndetested her first husband. When a man marries again, it is because he\nadored his first wife. Women try their luck; men risk theirs.']
qText:
You will never marry again, Lady Narborough, You were far too happy. When a woman marries again, it is because she
detested her first husband. When a man marries again, it is because he
adored his first wife. Women try their luck; men risk theirs.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Narborough wasn t perfect,']
qText: Narborough wasn t perfect,
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['If he had been, you would not have loved him, my dear lady,']
qText: If he had been, you would not have loved him, my dear lady,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Women love us for our defects. If we have enough of them,
they will forgive us everything, even our intellects. You will never
ask me to dinner again after saying this, I am afraid, Lady Narborough,
but it is quite true.']
qText:
Women love us for our defects. If we have enough of them,
they will forgive us everything, even our intellects. You will never
ask me to dinner again after saying this, I am afraid, Lady Narborough,
but it is quite true.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Of course it is true, Lord Henry. If we women did not love you for
your defects, where would you all be? Not one of you would ever be
married. You would be a set of unfortunate bachelors. Not, however,
that that would alter you much. Nowadays all the married men live like
bachelors, and all the bachelors like married men.']
qText:
Of course it is true, Lord Henry. If we women did not love you for
your defects, where would you all be? Not one of you would ever be
married. You would be a set of unfortunate bachelors. Not, however,
that that would alter you much. Nowadays all the married men live like
bachelors, and all the bachelors like married men.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['_Fin de si cle_,']
qText: _Fin de si cle_,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['_Fin du globe_,']
qText: _Fin du globe_,
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['I wish it were _fin du globe_,', 'Life is a\ngreat disappointment.']
qText:
I wish it were _fin du globe_, Life is a
great disappointment.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Ah, my dear,', 'don t
tell me that you have exhausted life. When a man says that one knows
that life has exhausted him. Lord Henry is very wicked, and I sometimes
wish that I had been; but you are made to be good you look so good. I
must find you a nice wife. Lord Henry, don t you think that Mr. Gray
should get married?']
qText:
Ah, my dear, don t
tell me that you have exhausted life. When a man says that one knows
that life has exhausted him. Lord Henry is very wicked, and I sometimes
wish that I had been; but you are made to be good you look so good. I
must find you a nice wife. Lord Henry, don t you think that Mr. Gray
should get married?
speaker: Lady Narborough
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray']], [['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['I am always telling him so, Lady Narborough,']
qText: I am always telling him so, Lady Narborough,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Well, we must look out for a suitable match for him. I shall go\nthrough Debrett carefully to-night and draw out a list of all the\neligible young ladies.']
qText:
Well, we must look out for a suitable match for him. I shall go
through Debrett carefully to-night and draw out a list of all the
eligible young ladies.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['With their ages, Lady Narborough?']
qText: With their ages, Lady Narborough?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Of course, with their ages, slightly edited. But nothing must be done\nin a hurry. I want it to be what _The Morning Post_ calls a suitable\nalliance, and I want you both to be happy.']
qText:
Of course, with their ages, slightly edited. But nothing must be done
in a hurry. I want it to be what _The Morning Post_ calls a suitable
alliance, and I want you both to be happy.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['What nonsense people talk about happy marriages!', 'A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love\nher.']
qText:
What nonsense people talk about happy marriages! A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love
her.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Ah! what a cynic you are!', 'You must come and dine with me soon again.
You are really an admirable tonic, much better than what Sir Andrew
prescribes for me. You must tell me what people you would like to meet,
though. I want it to be a delightful gathering.']
qText:
Ah! what a cynic you are! You must come and dine with me soon again.
You are really an admirable tonic, much better than what Sir Andrew
prescribes for me. You must tell me what people you would like to meet,
though. I want it to be a delightful gathering.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['I like men who have a future and women who have a past,', 'Or do you think that would make it a petticoat party?']
qText: I like men who have a future and women who have a past, Or do you think that would make it a petticoat party?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I fear so,']
qText: I fear so,
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['A thousand pardons,\nmy dear Lady Ruxton,', 'I didn t see you hadn t finished your\ncigarette.']
qText:
A thousand pardons,
my dear Lady Ruxton, I didn t see you hadn t finished your
cigarette.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['Never mind, Lady Narborough. I smoke a great deal too much. I am going\nto limit myself, for the future.']
qText:
Never mind, Lady Narborough. I smoke a great deal too much. I am going
to limit myself, for the future.
speaker: Lady Ruxton

qTextArr: ['Pray don t, Lady Ruxton,', 'Moderation is a fatal\nthing. Enough is as bad as a meal. More than enough is as good as a\nfeast.']
qText:
Pray don t, Lady Ruxton, Moderation is a fatal
thing. Enough is as bad as a meal. More than enough is as good as a
feast.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You must come and explain that\nto me some afternoon, Lord Henry. It sounds a fascinating theory,']
qText:
You must come and explain that
to me some afternoon, Lord Henry. It sounds a fascinating theory,
speaker: Lady Ruxton

qTextArr: ['Now, mind you don t stay too long over your politics and scandal,', 'If you do, we are sure to\nsquabble upstairs.']
qText:
Now, mind you don t stay too long over your politics and scandal, If you do, we are sure to
squabble upstairs.
speaker: Lady Narborough

qTextArr: ['Are you better, my dear fellow?', 'You seemed rather out of\nsorts at dinner.']
qText:
Are you better, my dear fellow? You seemed rather out of
sorts at dinner.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I am quite well, Harry. I am tired. That is all.']
qText: I am quite well, Harry. I am tired. That is all.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You were charming last night. The little duchess is quite devoted to\nyou. She tells me she is going down to Selby.']
qText:
You were charming last night. The little duchess is quite devoted to
you. She tells me she is going down to Selby.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth']]]

qTextArr: ['She has promised to come on the twentieth.']
qText: She has promised to come on the twentieth.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Is Monmouth to be there, too?']
qText: Is Monmouth to be there, too?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh, yes, Harry.']
qText: Oh, yes, Harry.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['He bores me dreadfully, almost as much as he bores her. She is very
clever, too clever for a woman. She lacks the indefinable charm of
weakness. It is the feet of clay that make the gold of the image
precious. Her feet are very pretty, but they are not feet of clay.
White porcelain feet, if you like. They have been through the fire, and
what fire does not destroy, it hardens. She has had experiences.']
qText:
He bores me dreadfully, almost as much as he bores her. She is very
clever, too clever for a woman. She lacks the indefinable charm of
weakness. It is the feet of clay that make the gold of the image
precious. Her feet are very pretty, but they are not feet of clay.
White porcelain feet, if you like. They have been through the fire, and
what fire does not destroy, it hardens. She has had experiences.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth']]]

qTextArr: ['How long has she been married?']
qText: How long has she been married?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['An eternity, she tells me. I believe, according to the peerage, it is\nten years, but ten years with Monmouth must have been like eternity,\nwith time thrown in. Who else is coming?']
qText:
An eternity, she tells me. I believe, according to the peerage, it is
ten years, but ten years with Monmouth must have been like eternity,
with time thrown in. Who else is coming?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh, the Willoughbys, Lord Rugby and his wife, our hostess, Geoffrey\nClouston, the usual set. I have asked Lord Grotrian.']
qText:
Oh, the Willoughbys, Lord Rugby and his wife, our hostess, Geoffrey
Clouston, the usual set. I have asked Lord Grotrian.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I like him,', 'A great many people don t, but I find\nhim charming. He atones for being occasionally somewhat overdressed by\nbeing always absolutely over-educated. He is a very modern type.']
qText:
I like him, A great many people don t, but I find
him charming. He atones for being occasionally somewhat overdressed by
being always absolutely over-educated. He is a very modern type.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I don t know if he will be able to come, Harry. He may have to go to\nMonte Carlo with his father.']
qText:
I don t know if he will be able to come, Harry. He may have to go to
Monte Carlo with his father.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Ah! what a nuisance people s people are! Try and make him come. By the\nway, Dorian, you ran off very early last night. You left before eleven.\nWhat did you do afterwards? Did you go straight home?']
qText:
Ah! what a nuisance people s people are! Try and make him come. By the
way, Dorian, you ran off very early last night. You left before eleven.
What did you do afterwards? Did you go straight home?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['No, Harry,', 'I did not get home till nearly three.']
qText: No, Harry, I did not get home till nearly three.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Did you go to the club?']
qText: Did you go to the club?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Yes,', 'No, I don t mean that. I
didn t go to the club. I walked about. I forget what I did.... How
inquisitive you are, Harry! You always want to know what one has been
doing. I always want to forget what I have been doing. I came in at
half-past two, if you wish to know the exact time. I had left my
latch-key at home, and my servant had to let me in. If you want any
corroborative evidence on the subject, you can ask him.']
qText:
Yes, No, I don t mean that. I
didn t go to the club. I walked about. I forget what I did.... How
inquisitive you are, Harry! You always want to know what one has been
doing. I always want to forget what I have been doing. I came in at
half-past two, if you wish to know the exact time. I had left my
latch-key at home, and my servant had to let me in. If you want any
corroborative evidence on the subject, you can ask him.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[], [['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Francis'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Francis']]]

qTextArr:
['My dear fellow, as if I cared! Let
us go up to the drawing-room. No sherry, thank you, Mr. Chapman.
Something has happened to you, Dorian. Tell me what it is. You are not
yourself to-night.']
qText:
My dear fellow, as if I cared! Let
us go up to the drawing-room. No sherry, thank you, Mr. Chapman.
Something has happened to you, Dorian. Tell me what it is. You are not
yourself to-night.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['Don t mind me, Harry. I am irritable, and out of temper. I shall come\nround and see you to-morrow, or next day. Make my excuses to Lady\nNarborough. I shan t go upstairs. I shall go home. I must go home.']
qText:
Don t mind me, Harry. I am irritable, and out of temper. I shall come
round and see you to-morrow, or next day. Make my excuses to Lady
Narborough. I shan t go upstairs. I shall go home. I must go home.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['All right, Dorian. I dare say I shall see you to-morrow at tea-time.\nThe duchess is coming.']
qText:
All right, Dorian. I dare say I shall see you to-morrow at tea-time.
The duchess is coming.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I will try to be there, Harry,']
qText: I will try to be there, Harry,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It is too far for me,']
qText: It is too far for me,
speaker: Hansom Driver

qTextArr: ['Here is a sovereign for you,', 'You shall have another if\nyou drive fast.']
qText:
Here is a sovereign for you, You shall have another if
you drive fast.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['All right, sir,', 'you will be there in an hour,']
qText: All right, sir, you will be there in an hour,
speaker: Hansom Driver

qTextArr: ['Somewhere about here, sir, ain t it?']
qText: Somewhere about here, sir, ain t it?
speaker: Hansom Driver

qTextArr: ['This will do,']
qText: This will do,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You here, Adrian?']
qText: You here, Adrian?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Where else should I be?', 'None of the chaps\nwill speak to me now.']
qText:
Where else should I be? None of the chaps
will speak to me now.
speaker: Adrian Singleton

qTextArr: ['I thought you had left England.']
qText: I thought you had left England.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Darlington is not going to do anything. My brother paid the bill at\nlast. George doesn t speak to me either.... I don t care,', 'As long as one has this stuff, one doesn t want friends.\nI think I have had too many friends.']
qText:
Darlington is not going to do anything. My brother paid the bill at
last. George doesn t speak to me either.... I don t care, As long as one has this stuff, one doesn t want friends.
I think I have had too many friends.
speaker: Adrian Singleton

qTextArr: ['I am going on to the other place,']
qText: I am going on to the other place,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['On the wharf?']
qText: On the wharf?
speaker: Adrian Singleton

qText: Yes.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['That mad-cat is sure to be there. They won t have her in this place\nnow.']
qText:
That mad-cat is sure to be there. They won t have her in this place
now.
speaker: Adrian Singleton

qTextArr: ['I am sick of women who love one. Women\nwho hate one are much more interesting. Besides, the stuff is better.']
qText:
I am sick of women who love one. Women
who hate one are much more interesting. Besides, the stuff is better.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Much the same.']
qText: Much the same.
speaker: Adrian Singleton

qTextArr: ['I like it better. Come and have something to drink. I must have\nsomething.']
qText:
I like it better. Come and have something to drink. I must have
something.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I don t want anything,']
qText: I don t want anything,
speaker: Adrian Singleton

qTextArr: ['Never mind.']
qText: Never mind.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['We are very proud to-night,']
qText: We are very proud to-night,
speaker: One Of The Women

qTextArr: ['For God s sake don t talk to me,', 'What do you want? Money? Here it is. Don t ever talk to me\nagain.']
qText:
For God s sake don t talk to me, What do you want? Money? Here it is. Don t ever talk to me
again.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It s no use,', 'I don t care to go back. What\ndoes it matter? I am quite happy here.']
qText:
It s no use, I don t care to go back. What
does it matter? I am quite happy here.
speaker: Adrian Singleton

qTextArr: ['You will write to me if you want anything, won t you?']
qText: You will write to me if you want anything, won t you?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Perhaps.']
qText: Perhaps.
speaker: Adrian Singleton

qTextArr: ['Good night, then.']
qText: Good night, then.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Good night,']
qText: Good night,
speaker: Adrian Singleton

qTextArr: ['There goes the devil s bargain!']
qText: There goes the devil s bargain!
speaker: One Of The Women

qTextArr: ['Curse you!', 'don t call me that.']
qText: Curse you! don t call me that.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Prince Charming is what you like to be\ncalled, ain t it?']
qText:
Prince Charming is what you like to be
called, ain t it?
speaker: One Of The Women

qTextArr: ['What do you want?']
qText: What do you want?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Keep quiet,', 'If you stir, I shoot you.']
qText: Keep quiet, If you stir, I shoot you.
speaker: James Vane

qTextArr: ['You are mad. What have I done to you?']
qText: You are mad. What have I done to you?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You wrecked the life of Sibyl Vane,']
qText: You wrecked the life of Sibyl Vane,
speaker: James Vane

qTextArr:
['and Sibyl Vane
was my sister. She killed herself. I know it. Her death is at your
door. I swore I would kill you in return. For years I have sought you.
I had no clue, no trace. The two people who could have described you
were dead. I knew nothing of you but the pet name she used to call you.
I heard it to-night by chance. Make your peace with God, for to-night
you are going to die.']
qText:
and Sibyl Vane
was my sister. She killed herself. I know it. Her death is at your
door. I swore I would kill you in return. For years I have sought you.
I had no clue, no trace. The two people who could have described you
were dead. I knew nothing of you but the pet name she used to call you.
I heard it to-night by chance. Make your peace with God, for to-night
you are going to die.
speaker: James Vane
menEnts: [[['Sibyl Vane'], ['Sibyl Vane'], ['Sibyl Vane'], ['Sibyl Vane'], ['Sibyl Vane'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Sibyl Vane'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['I never knew her,', 'I\nnever heard of her. You are mad.']
qText:
I never knew her, I
never heard of her. You are mad.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You had better confess your sin, for as sure as I am James Vane, you\nare going to die.']
qText:
You had better confess your sin, for as sure as I am James Vane, you
are going to die.
speaker: James Vane

qTextArr: ['Down on your knees!', 'I give you\none minute to make your peace no more. I go on board to-night for\nIndia, and I must do my job first. One minute. That s all.']
qText:
Down on your knees! I give you
one minute to make your peace no more. I go on board to-night for
India, and I must do my job first. One minute. That s all.
speaker: James Vane

qTextArr: ['Stop,', 'How long ago is it since your sister died? Quick, tell me!']
qText: Stop, How long ago is it since your sister died? Quick, tell me!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Eighteen years,', 'Why do you ask me? What do years\nmatter?']
qText:
Eighteen years, Why do you ask me? What do years
matter?
speaker: James Vane

qTextArr: ['Eighteen years,', 'Eighteen years! Set me under the lamp and look at my face!']
qText: Eighteen years, Eighteen years! Set me under the lamp and look at my face!
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['My God! my God!', 'and\nI would have murdered you!']
qText:
My God! my God! and
I would have murdered you!
speaker: James Vane

qTextArr: ['You have been on the brink of\ncommitting a terrible crime, my man,', 'Let this be a warning to you not to take vengeance into your own\nhands.']
qText:
You have been on the brink of
committing a terrible crime, my man, Let this be a warning to you not to take vengeance into your own
hands.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Forgive me, sir,', 'I was deceived. A chance word\nI heard in that damned den set me on the wrong track.']
qText:
Forgive me, sir, I was deceived. A chance word
I heard in that damned den set me on the wrong track.
speaker: James Vane

qTextArr: ['You had better go home and put that pistol away, or you may get into\ntrouble,']
qText:
You had better go home and put that pistol away, or you may get into
trouble,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Why didn t you kill him?', 'I knew you were following him when you rushed out from\nDaly s. You fool! You should have killed him. He has lots of money, and\nhe s as bad as bad.']
qText:
Why didn t you kill him? I knew you were following him when you rushed out from
Daly s. You fool! You should have killed him. He has lots of money, and
he s as bad as bad.
speaker: One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar
menEnts: [[['James Vane'], ['Dorian Gray']], [['James Vane'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['James Vane'], ['James Vane'], ['James Vane'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr:
['He is not the man I am looking for,', 'and I want no man s
money. I want a man s life. The man whose life I want must be nearly
forty now. This one is little more than a boy. Thank God, I have not
got his blood upon my hands.']
qText:
He is not the man I am looking for, and I want no man s
money. I want a man s life. The man whose life I want must be nearly
forty now. This one is little more than a boy. Thank God, I have not
got his blood upon my hands.
speaker: James Vane
addressee: ['One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar']
menTexts: [['He', 'the man I am looking for'], ['The man whose life I want', 'This one', 'his']]

qTextArr: ['Little more than a boy!', 'Why, man, it s nigh on eighteen years since Prince Charming made me\nwhat I am.']
qText:
Little more than a boy! Why, man, it s nigh on eighteen years since Prince Charming made me
what I am.
speaker: One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar

qTextArr: ['You lie!']
qText: You lie!
speaker: James Vane
addressee: ['One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar']

qTextArr: ['Before God I am telling the truth,']
qText: Before God I am telling the truth,
speaker: One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar

qTextArr: ['Before God?']
qText: Before God?
speaker: James Vane
addressee: ['One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar']

qTextArr:
['Strike me dumb if it ain t so. He is the worst one that comes here.
They say he has sold himself to the devil for a pretty face. It s nigh
on eighteen years since I met him. He hasn t changed much since then. I
have, though,']
qText:
Strike me dumb if it ain t so. He is the worst one that comes here.
They say he has sold himself to the devil for a pretty face. It s nigh
on eighteen years since I met him. He hasn t changed much since then. I
have, though,
speaker: One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar

qTextArr: ['You swear this?']
qText: You swear this?
speaker: James Vane
addressee: ['One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar']

qTextArr: ['I swear it,']
qText: I swear it,
speaker: One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar
refExp: came in hoarse echo from her

qTextArr: ['But don t give\nme away to him,', 'I am afraid of him. Let me have some\nmoney for my night s lodging.']
qText:
But don t give
me away to him, I am afraid of him. Let me have some
money for my night s lodging.
speaker: One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar

qTextArr: ['What are you two talking about?', 'I hope Dorian has told you about\nmy plan for rechristening everything, Gladys. It is a delightful idea.']
qText:
What are you two talking about? I hope Dorian has told you about
my plan for rechristening everything, Gladys. It is a delightful idea.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray', 'Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Gladys']], [['Dorian Gray'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth']]]

qTextArr: ['But I don t want to be rechristened, Harry,', 'I am quite satisfied with\nmy own name, and I am sure Mr. Gray should be satisfied with his.']
qText:
But I don t want to be rechristened, Harry, I am quite satisfied with
my own name, and I am sure Mr. Gray should be satisfied with his.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr:
['My dear Gladys, I would not alter either name for the world. They are
both perfect. I was thinking chiefly of flowers. Yesterday I cut an
orchid, for my button-hole. It was a marvellous spotted thing, as
effective as the seven deadly sins. In a thoughtless moment I asked one
of the gardeners what it was called. He told me it was a fine specimen
of _Robinsoniana_, or something dreadful of that kind. It is a sad
truth, but we have lost the faculty of giving lovely names to things.
Names are everything. I never quarrel with actions. My one quarrel is
with words. That is the reason I hate vulgar realism in literature. The
man who could call a spade a spade should be compelled to use one. It
is the only thing he is fit for.']
qText:
My dear Gladys, I would not alter either name for the world. They are
both perfect. I was thinking chiefly of flowers. Yesterday I cut an
orchid, for my button-hole. It was a marvellous spotted thing, as
effective as the seven deadly sins. In a thoughtless moment I asked one
of the gardeners what it was called. He told me it was a fine specimen
of _Robinsoniana_, or something dreadful of that kind. It is a sad
truth, but we have lost the faculty of giving lovely names to things.
Names are everything. I never quarrel with actions. My one quarrel is
with words. That is the reason I hate vulgar realism in literature. The
man who could call a spade a spade should be compelled to use one. It
is the only thing he is fit for.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Then what should we call you, Harry?']
qText: Then what should we call you, Harry?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['His name is Prince Paradox,']
qText: His name is Prince Paradox,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I recognize him in a flash,']
qText: I recognize him in a flash,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['I won t hear of it,', 'From a\nlabel there is no escape! I refuse the title.']
qText:
I won t hear of it, From a
label there is no escape! I refuse the title.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Royalties may not abdicate,']
qText: Royalties may not abdicate,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth
refExp: fell as a warning from pretty lips

qTextArr: ['You wish me to defend my throne, then?']
qText: You wish me to defend my throne, then?
speaker: Lord Henry

qText: Yes.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['I give the truths of to-morrow.']
qText: I give the truths of to-morrow.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I prefer the mistakes of to-day,']
qText: I prefer the mistakes of to-day,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['You disarm me, Gladys,']
qText: You disarm me, Gladys,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Of your shield, Harry, not of your spear.']
qText: Of your shield, Harry, not of your spear.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['I never tilt against beauty,']
qText: I never tilt against beauty,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['That is your error, Harry, believe me. You value beauty far too much.']
qText: That is your error, Harry, believe me. You value beauty far too much.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['How can you say that? I admit that I think that it is better to be\nbeautiful than to be good. But on the other hand, no one is more ready\nthan I am to acknowledge that it is better to be good than to be ugly.']
qText:
How can you say that? I admit that I think that it is better to be
beautiful than to be good. But on the other hand, no one is more ready
than I am to acknowledge that it is better to be good than to be ugly.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Ugliness is one of the seven deadly sins, then?', 'What becomes of your simile about the orchid?']
qText: Ugliness is one of the seven deadly sins, then? What becomes of your simile about the orchid?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Ugliness is one of the seven deadly virtues, Gladys. You, as a good\nTory, must not underrate them. Beer, the Bible, and the seven deadly\nvirtues have made our England what she is.']
qText:
Ugliness is one of the seven deadly virtues, Gladys. You, as a good
Tory, must not underrate them. Beer, the Bible, and the seven deadly
virtues have made our England what she is.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You don t like your country, then?']
qText: You don t like your country, then?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['I live in it.']
qText: I live in it.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['That you may censure it the better.']
qText: That you may censure it the better.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Would you have me take the verdict of Europe on it?']
qText: Would you have me take the verdict of Europe on it?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['What do they say of us?']
qText: What do they say of us?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['That Tartuffe has emigrated to England and opened a shop.']
qText: That Tartuffe has emigrated to England and opened a shop.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Is that yours, Harry?']
qText: Is that yours, Harry?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['I give it to you.']
qText: I give it to you.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I could not use it. It is too true.']
qText: I could not use it. It is too true.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['You need not be afraid. Our countrymen never recognize a description.']
qText: You need not be afraid. Our countrymen never recognize a description.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['They are practical.']
qText: They are practical.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['They are more cunning than practical. When they make up their ledger,\nthey balance stupidity by wealth, and vice by hypocrisy.']
qText:
They are more cunning than practical. When they make up their ledger,
they balance stupidity by wealth, and vice by hypocrisy.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Still, we have done great things.']
qText: Still, we have done great things.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Great things have been thrust on us, Gladys.']
qText: Great things have been thrust on us, Gladys.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['We have carried their burden.']
qText: We have carried their burden.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Only as far as the Stock Exchange.']
qText: Only as far as the Stock Exchange.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I believe in the race,']
qText: I believe in the race,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['It represents the survival of the pushing.']
qText: It represents the survival of the pushing.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['It has development.']
qText: It has development.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Decay fascinates me more.']
qText: Decay fascinates me more.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['What of art?']
qText: What of art?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['It is a malady.']
qText: It is a malady.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Love?']
qText: Love?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['An illusion.']
qText: An illusion.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Religion?']
qText: Religion?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['The fashionable substitute for belief.']
qText: The fashionable substitute for belief.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You are a sceptic.']
qText: You are a sceptic.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Never! Scepticism is the beginning of faith.']
qText: Never! Scepticism is the beginning of faith.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['What are you?']
qText: What are you?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['To define is to limit.']
qText: To define is to limit.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Give me a clue.']
qText: Give me a clue.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Threads snap. You would lose your way in the labyrinth.']
qText: Threads snap. You would lose your way in the labyrinth.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You bewilder me. Let us talk of some one else.']
qText: You bewilder me. Let us talk of some one else.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Our host is a delightful topic. Years ago he was christened Prince\nCharming.']
qText:
Our host is a delightful topic. Years ago he was christened Prince
Charming.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Ah! don t remind me of that,']
qText: Ah! don t remind me of that,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Our host is rather horrid this evening,', 'I believe he thinks that Monmouth married me on purely\nscientific principles as the best specimen he could find of a modern\nbutterfly.']
qText:
Our host is rather horrid this evening, I believe he thinks that Monmouth married me on purely
scientific principles as the best specimen he could find of a modern
butterfly.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Well, I hope he won t stick pins into you, Duchess,']
qText: Well, I hope he won t stick pins into you, Duchess,
speaker: Dorian Gray
