qTextArr: ['Oh! my maid does that already, Mr. Gray, when she is annoyed with me.']
qText: Oh! my maid does that already, Mr. Gray, when she is annoyed with me.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['And what does she get annoyed with you about, Duchess?']
qText: And what does she get annoyed with you about, Duchess?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['For the most trivial things, Mr. Gray, I assure you. Usually because I\ncome in at ten minutes to nine and tell her that I must be dressed by\nhalf-past eight.']
qText:
For the most trivial things, Mr. Gray, I assure you. Usually because I
come in at ten minutes to nine and tell her that I must be dressed by
half-past eight.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['How unreasonable of her! You should give her warning.']
qText: How unreasonable of her! You should give her warning.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['I daren t, Mr. Gray. Why, she invents hats for me. You remember the
one I wore at Lady Hilstone s garden-party? You don t, but it is nice
of you to pretend that you do. Well, she made it out of nothing. All
good hats are made out of nothing.']
qText:
I daren t, Mr. Gray. Why, she invents hats for me. You remember the
one I wore at Lady Hilstone s garden-party? You don t, but it is nice
of you to pretend that you do. Well, she made it out of nothing. All
good hats are made out of nothing.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Like all good reputations, Gladys,', 'Every\neffect that one produces gives one an enemy. To be popular one must be\na mediocrity.']
qText:
Like all good reputations, Gladys, Every
effect that one produces gives one an enemy. To be popular one must be
a mediocrity.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Not with women,', 'and women rule
the world. I assure you we can t bear mediocrities. We women, as some
one says, love with our ears, just as you men love with your eyes, if
you ever love at all.']
qText:
Not with women, and women rule
the world. I assure you we can t bear mediocrities. We women, as some
one says, love with our ears, just as you men love with your eyes, if
you ever love at all.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['It seems to me that we never do anything else,']
qText: It seems to me that we never do anything else,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Ah! then, you never really love, Mr. Gray,']
qText: Ah! then, you never really love, Mr. Gray,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr:
['My dear Gladys!', 'How can you say that? Romance
lives by repetition, and repetition converts an appetite into an art.
Besides, each time that one loves is the only time one has ever loved.
Difference of object does not alter singleness of passion. It merely
intensifies it. We can have in life but one great experience at best,
and the secret of life is to reproduce that experience as often as
possible.']
qText:
My dear Gladys! How can you say that? Romance
lives by repetition, and repetition converts an appetite into an art.
Besides, each time that one loves is the only time one has ever loved.
Difference of object does not alter singleness of passion. It merely
intensifies it. We can have in life but one great experience at best,
and the secret of life is to reproduce that experience as often as
possible.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Even when one has been wounded by it, Harry?']
qText: Even when one has been wounded by it, Harry?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Especially when one has been wounded by it,']
qText: Especially when one has been wounded by it,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['What do you say to that, Mr. Gray?']
qText: What do you say to that, Mr. Gray?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['I always agree with Harry, Duchess.']
qText: I always agree with Harry, Duchess.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Even when he is wrong?']
qText: Even when he is wrong?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Harry is never wrong, Duchess.']
qText: Harry is never wrong, Duchess.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['And does his philosophy make you happy?']
qText: And does his philosophy make you happy?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['I have never searched for happiness. Who wants happiness? I have\nsearched for pleasure.']
qText:
I have never searched for happiness. Who wants happiness? I have
searched for pleasure.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['And found it, Mr. Gray?']
qText: And found it, Mr. Gray?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Often. Too often.']
qText: Often. Too often.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I am searching for peace,', 'and if I\ndon t go and dress, I shall have none this evening.']
qText:
I am searching for peace, and if I
don t go and dress, I shall have none this evening.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Let me get you some orchids, Duchess,']
qText: Let me get you some orchids, Duchess,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You are flirting disgracefully with him,', 'You had better take care. He is very fascinating.']
qText: You are flirting disgracefully with him, You had better take care. He is very fascinating.
speaker: Lord Henry
refExp: said Lord Henry to his cousin
menEnts: [[['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Dorian Gray']], [['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['If he were not, there would be no battle.']
qText: If he were not, there would be no battle.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Greek meets Greek, then?']
qText: Greek meets Greek, then?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I am on the side of the Trojans. They fought for a woman.']
qText: I am on the side of the Trojans. They fought for a woman.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['They were defeated.']
qText: They were defeated.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['There are worse things than capture,']
qText: There are worse things than capture,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['You gallop with a loose rein.']
qText: You gallop with a loose rein.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Pace gives life,']
qText: Pace gives life,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['I shall write it in my diary to-night.']
qText: I shall write it in my diary to-night.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['What?']
qText: What?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['That a burnt child loves the fire.']
qText: That a burnt child loves the fire.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I am not even singed. My wings are untouched.']
qText: I am not even singed. My wings are untouched.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['You use them for everything, except flight.']
qText: You use them for everything, except flight.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Courage has passed from men to women. It is a new experience for us.']
qText: Courage has passed from men to women. It is a new experience for us.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['You have a rival.']
qText: You have a rival.
speaker: Lord Henry

qText: Who?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Lady Narborough,', 'She perfectly adores\nhim.']
qText:
Lady Narborough, She perfectly adores
him.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You fill me with apprehension. The appeal to antiquity is fatal to us\nwho are romanticists.']
qText:
You fill me with apprehension. The appeal to antiquity is fatal to us
who are romanticists.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Romanticists! You have all the methods of science.']
qText: Romanticists! You have all the methods of science.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Men have educated us.']
qText: Men have educated us.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['But not explained you.']
qText: But not explained you.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Describe us as a sex,']
qText: Describe us as a sex,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Sphinxes without secrets.']
qText: Sphinxes without secrets.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['How long Mr. Gray is!', 'Let us\ngo and help him. I have not yet told him the colour of my frock.']
qText:
How long Mr. Gray is! Let us
go and help him. I have not yet told him the colour of my frock.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray']], [['Lord Henry', 'Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['Ah! you must suit your frock to his flowers, Gladys.']
qText: Ah! you must suit your frock to his flowers, Gladys.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth']]]

qTextArr: ['That would be a premature surrender.']
qText: That would be a premature surrender.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Romantic art begins with its climax.']
qText: Romantic art begins with its climax.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I must keep an opportunity for retreat.']
qText: I must keep an opportunity for retreat.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['In the Parthian manner?']
qText: In the Parthian manner?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['They found safety in the desert. I could not do that.']
qText: They found safety in the desert. I could not do that.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Women are not always allowed a choice,']
qText: Women are not always allowed a choice,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['What has happened?', 'Oh! I remember. Am I safe here, Harry?']
qText: What has happened? Oh! I remember. Am I safe here, Harry?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['My dear Dorian,', 'you merely fainted. That was\nall. You must have overtired yourself. You had better not come down to\ndinner. I will take your place.']
qText:
My dear Dorian, you merely fainted. That was
all. You must have overtired yourself. You had better not come down to
dinner. I will take your place.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['No, I will come down,', 'I would\nrather come down. I must not be alone.']
qText:
No, I will come down, I would
rather come down. I must not be alone.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Have you had good sport, Geoffrey?']
qText: Have you had good sport, Geoffrey?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Not very good, Dorian. I think most of the birds have gone to the\nopen. I dare say it will be better after lunch, when we get to new\nground.']
qText:
Not very good, Dorian. I think most of the birds have gone to the
open. I dare say it will be better after lunch, when we get to new
ground.
speaker: Sir Geoffrey Clouston

qTextArr: ['Don t shoot it, Geoffrey. Let it live.']
qText: Don t shoot it, Geoffrey. Let it live.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['What nonsense, Dorian!']
qText: What nonsense, Dorian!
speaker: Sir Geoffrey Clouston

qTextArr: ['Good heavens! I have hit a beater!']
qText: Good heavens! I have hit a beater!
speaker: Sir Geoffrey Clouston

qTextArr: ['What an\nass the man was to get in front of the guns! Stop shooting there!', 'A man is hurt.']
qText:
What an
ass the man was to get in front of the guns! Stop shooting there! A man is hurt.
speaker: Sir Geoffrey Clouston

qTextArr: ['Where, sir? Where is he?']
qText: Where, sir? Where is he?
speaker: Thornton

qTextArr: ['Here,', 'Why on earth don t you keep your men back? Spoiled my shooting for the\nday.']
qText:
Here, Why on earth don t you keep your men back? Spoiled my shooting for the
day.
speaker: Sir Geoffrey Clouston

qTextArr: ['Dorian,', 'I had better tell them that the shooting is\nstopped for to-day. It would not look well to go on.']
qText:
Dorian, I had better tell them that the shooting is
stopped for to-day. It would not look well to go on.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I wish it were stopped for ever, Harry,', 'The\nwhole thing is hideous and cruel. Is the man ...?']
qText:
I wish it were stopped for ever, Harry, The
whole thing is hideous and cruel. Is the man ...?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I am afraid so,', 'He got the whole charge of shot\nin his chest. He must have died almost instantaneously. Come; let us go\nhome.']
qText:
I am afraid so, He got the whole charge of shot
in his chest. He must have died almost instantaneously. Come; let us go
home.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['It is a bad omen, Harry, a very bad omen.']
qText: It is a bad omen, Harry, a very bad omen.
speaker: Dorian Gray
refExp: Dorian looked at Lord Henry and said

qTextArr:
['What is?', 'Oh! this accident, I suppose. My dear
fellow, it can t be helped. It was the man s own fault. Why did he get
in front of the guns? Besides, it is nothing to us. It is rather
awkward for Geoffrey, of course. It does not do to pepper beaters. It
makes people think that one is a wild shot. And Geoffrey is not; he
shoots very straight. But there is no use talking about the matter.']
qText:
What is? Oh! this accident, I suppose. My dear
fellow, it can t be helped. It was the man s own fault. Why did he get
in front of the guns? Besides, it is nothing to us. It is rather
awkward for Geoffrey, of course. It does not do to pepper beaters. It
makes people think that one is a wild shot. And Geoffrey is not; he
shoots very straight. But there is no use talking about the matter.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[], [['James Vane'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Sir Geoffrey Clouston'], ['Sir Geoffrey Clouston'], ['Sir Geoffrey Clouston']]]

qTextArr: ['It is a bad omen, Harry. I feel as if something\nhorrible were going to happen to some of us. To myself, perhaps,']
qText:
It is a bad omen, Harry. I feel as if something
horrible were going to happen to some of us. To myself, perhaps,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['The only horrible thing in the world is
_ennui_, Dorian. That is the one sin for which there is no forgiveness.
But we are not likely to suffer from it unless these fellows keep
chattering about this thing at dinner. I must tell them that the
subject is to be tabooed. As for omens, there is no such thing as an
omen. Destiny does not send us heralds. She is too wise or too cruel
for that. Besides, what on earth could happen to you, Dorian? You have
everything in the world that a man can want. There is no one who would
not be delighted to change places with you.']
qText:
The only horrible thing in the world is
_ennui_, Dorian. That is the one sin for which there is no forgiveness.
But we are not likely to suffer from it unless these fellows keep
chattering about this thing at dinner. I must tell them that the
subject is to be tabooed. As for omens, there is no such thing as an
omen. Destiny does not send us heralds. She is too wise or too cruel
for that. Besides, what on earth could happen to you, Dorian? You have
everything in the world that a man can want. There is no one who would
not be delighted to change places with you.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr:
['There is no one with whom I would not change places, Harry. Don t
laugh like that. I am telling you the truth. The wretched peasant who
has just died is better off than I am. I have no terror of death. It is
the coming of death that terrifies me. Its monstrous wings seem to
wheel in the leaden air around me. Good heavens! don t you see a man
moving behind the trees there, watching me, waiting for me?']
qText:
There is no one with whom I would not change places, Harry. Don t
laugh like that. I am telling you the truth. The wretched peasant who
has just died is better off than I am. I have no terror of death. It is
the coming of death that terrifies me. Its monstrous wings seem to
wheel in the leaden air around me. Good heavens! don t you see a man
moving behind the trees there, watching me, waiting for me?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Yes,', 'I see the gardener waiting for
you. I suppose he wants to ask you what flowers you wish to have on the
table to-night. How absurdly nervous you are, my dear fellow! You must
come and see my doctor, when we get back to town.']
qText:
Yes, I see the gardener waiting for
you. I suppose he wants to ask you what flowers you wish to have on the
table to-night. How absurdly nervous you are, my dear fellow! You must
come and see my doctor, when we get back to town.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[], [['The Gardener'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['The Gardener'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr: ['Her\nGrace told me to wait for an answer,']
qText:
Her
Grace told me to wait for an answer,
speaker: The Gardener

qTextArr: ['Tell her Grace that I am coming\nin,']
qText:
Tell her Grace that I am coming
in,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['How fond women are of doing dangerous things!', 'It\nis one of the qualities in them that I admire most. A woman will flirt\nwith anybody in the world as long as other people are looking on.']
qText:
How fond women are of doing dangerous things! It
is one of the qualities in them that I admire most. A woman will flirt
with anybody in the world as long as other people are looking on.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['How fond you are of saying dangerous things, Harry! In the present\ninstance, you are quite astray. I like the duchess very much, but I\ndon t love her.']
qText:
How fond you are of saying dangerous things, Harry! In the present
instance, you are quite astray. I like the duchess very much, but I
don t love her.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth']]]

qTextArr: ['And the duchess loves you very much, but she likes you less, so you\nare excellently matched.']
qText:
And the duchess loves you very much, but she likes you less, so you
are excellently matched.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['You are talking scandal, Harry, and there is never any basis for\nscandal.']
qText:
You are talking scandal, Harry, and there is never any basis for
scandal.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['The basis of every scandal is an immoral certainty,']
qText: The basis of every scandal is an immoral certainty,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['You would sacrifice anybody, Harry, for the sake of an epigram.']
qText: You would sacrifice anybody, Harry, for the sake of an epigram.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['The world goes to the altar of its own accord,']
qText: The world goes to the altar of its own accord,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['I wish I could love,', 'But I seem to have lost the passion and forgotten the
desire. I am too much concentrated on myself. My own personality has
become a burden to me. I want to escape, to go away, to forget. It was
silly of me to come down here at all. I think I shall send a wire to
Harvey to have the yacht got ready. On a yacht one is safe.']
qText:
I wish I could love, But I seem to have lost the passion and forgotten the
desire. I am too much concentrated on myself. My own personality has
become a burden to me. I want to escape, to go away, to forget. It was
silly of me to come down here at all. I think I shall send a wire to
Harvey to have the yacht got ready. On a yacht one is safe.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Safe from what, Dorian? You are in some trouble. Why not tell me what\nit is? You know I would help you.']
qText:
Safe from what, Dorian? You are in some trouble. Why not tell me what
it is? You know I would help you.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I can t tell you, Harry,', 'And I dare say it is\nonly a fancy of mine. This unfortunate accident has upset me. I have a\nhorrible presentiment that something of the kind may happen to me.']
qText:
I can t tell you, Harry, And I dare say it is
only a fancy of mine. This unfortunate accident has upset me. I have a
horrible presentiment that something of the kind may happen to me.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['What nonsense!']
qText: What nonsense!
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I hope it is, but I can t help feeling it. Ah! here is the duchess,\nlooking like Artemis in a tailor-made gown. You see we have come back,\nDuchess.']
qText:
I hope it is, but I can t help feeling it. Ah! here is the duchess,
looking like Artemis in a tailor-made gown. You see we have come back,
Duchess.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth']]]

qTextArr: ['I have heard all about it, Mr. Gray,', 'Poor Geoffrey is\nterribly upset. And it seems that you asked him not to shoot the hare.\nHow curious!']
qText:
I have heard all about it, Mr. Gray, Poor Geoffrey is
terribly upset. And it seems that you asked him not to shoot the hare.
How curious!
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray']], [['Sir Geoffrey Clouston'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Sir Geoffrey Clouston']]]

qTextArr: ['Yes, it was very curious. I don t know what made me say it. Some whim,\nI suppose. It looked the loveliest of little live things. But I am\nsorry they told you about the man. It is a hideous subject.']
qText:
Yes, it was very curious. I don t know what made me say it. Some whim,
I suppose. It looked the loveliest of little live things. But I am
sorry they told you about the man. It is a hideous subject.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['It is an annoying subject,', 'It has no
psychological value at all. Now if Geoffrey had done the thing on
purpose, how interesting he would be! I should like to know some one
who had committed a real murder.']
qText:
It is an annoying subject, It has no
psychological value at all. Now if Geoffrey had done the thing on
purpose, how interesting he would be! I should like to know some one
who had committed a real murder.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['How horrid of you, Harry!', 'Isn t it, Mr. Gray?\nHarry, Mr. Gray is ill again. He is going to faint.']
qText:
How horrid of you, Harry! Isn t it, Mr. Gray?
Harry, Mr. Gray is ill again. He is going to faint.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr:
['It is nothing,
Duchess,', 'my nerves are dreadfully out of order. That is
all. I am afraid I walked too far this morning. I didn t hear what
Harry said. Was it very bad? You must tell me some other time. I think
I must go and lie down. You will excuse me, won t you?']
qText:
It is nothing,
Duchess, my nerves are dreadfully out of order. That is
all. I am afraid I walked too far this morning. I didn t hear what
Harry said. Was it very bad? You must tell me some other time. I think
I must go and lie down. You will excuse me, won t you?
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Duchess Of Monmouth']], [['Lord Henry'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth'], ['Duchess Of Monmouth']]]

qTextArr: ['Are you very much in love with him?']
qText: Are you very much in love with him?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I\nwish I knew,']
qText:
I
wish I knew,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Knowledge would be fatal. It is the uncertainty\nthat charms one. A mist makes things wonderful.']
qText:
Knowledge would be fatal. It is the uncertainty
that charms one. A mist makes things wonderful.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['One may lose one s way.']
qText: One may lose one s way.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['All ways end at the same point, my dear Gladys.']
qText: All ways end at the same point, my dear Gladys.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['What is that?']
qText: What is that?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Disillusion.']
qText: Disillusion.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['It was my _d but_ in life,']
qText: It was my _d but_ in life,
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['It came to you crowned.']
qText: It came to you crowned.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I am tired of strawberry leaves.']
qText: I am tired of strawberry leaves.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['They become you.']
qText: They become you.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Only in public.']
qText: Only in public.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['You would miss them,']
qText: You would miss them,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I will not part with a petal.']
qText: I will not part with a petal.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Monmouth has ears.']
qText: Monmouth has ears.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Old age is dull of hearing.']
qText: Old age is dull of hearing.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['Has he never been jealous?']
qText: Has he never been jealous?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I wish he had been.']
qText: I wish he had been.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['What are you looking\nfor?']
qText:
What are you looking
for?
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['The button from your foil,', 'You have dropped it.']
qText: The button from your foil, You have dropped it.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I have still the mask.']
qText: I have still the mask.
speaker: Duchess Of Monmouth

qTextArr: ['It makes your eyes lovelier,']
qText: It makes your eyes lovelier,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Send him in,']
qText: Send him in,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I suppose you have come about the unfortunate accident of this\nmorning, Thornton?']
qText:
I suppose you have come about the unfortunate accident of this
morning, Thornton?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir,']
qText: Yes, sir,
speaker: Thornton

qTextArr: ['Was the poor fellow married? Had he any people dependent on him?', 'If so, I should not like them to be left\nin want, and will send them any sum of money you may think necessary.']
qText:
Was the poor fellow married? Had he any people dependent on him? If so, I should not like them to be left
in want, and will send them any sum of money you may think necessary.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['We don t know who he is, sir. That is what I took the liberty of\ncoming to you about.']
qText:
We don t know who he is, sir. That is what I took the liberty of
coming to you about.
speaker: Thornton

qTextArr: ['Don t know who he is?', 'What do you mean?\nWasn t he one of your men?']
qText:
Don t know who he is? What do you mean?
Wasn t he one of your men?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['No, sir. Never saw him before. Seems like a sailor, sir.']
qText: No, sir. Never saw him before. Seems like a sailor, sir.
speaker: Thornton

qTextArr: ['A sailor?', 'Did you say a\nsailor?']
qText:
A sailor? Did you say a
sailor?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir. He looks as if he had been a sort of sailor; tattooed on\nboth arms, and that kind of thing.']
qText:
Yes, sir. He looks as if he had been a sort of sailor; tattooed on
both arms, and that kind of thing.
speaker: Thornton

qTextArr: ['Was there anything found on him?', 'Anything that would tell his\nname?']
qText:
Was there anything found on him? Anything that would tell his
name?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Some money, sir not much, and a six-shooter. There was no name of any\nkind. A decent-looking man, sir, but rough-like. A sort of sailor we\nthink.']
qText:
Some money, sir not much, and a six-shooter. There was no name of any
kind. A decent-looking man, sir, but rough-like. A sort of sailor we
think.
speaker: Thornton

qTextArr: ['Where is the body?', 'Quick! I must\nsee it at once.']
qText:
Where is the body? Quick! I must
see it at once.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['It is in an empty stable in the Home Farm, sir. The folk don t like to\nhave that sort of thing in their houses. They say a corpse brings bad\nluck.']
qText:
It is in an empty stable in the Home Farm, sir. The folk don t like to
have that sort of thing in their houses. They say a corpse brings bad
luck.
speaker: Thornton

qTextArr: ['The Home Farm! Go there at once and meet me. Tell one of the grooms to\nbring my horse round. No. Never mind. I ll go to the stables myself. It\nwill save time.']
qText:
The Home Farm! Go there at once and meet me. Tell one of the grooms to
bring my horse round. No. Never mind. I ll go to the stables myself. It
will save time.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Take that thing off the face. I wish to see it,']
qText: Take that thing off the face. I wish to see it,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['There is no use your telling me that you are going to be good,', 'You are quite perfect. Pray, don t change.']
qText: There is no use your telling me that you are going to be good, You are quite perfect. Pray, don t change.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['No, Harry, I have done too many dreadful\nthings in my life. I am not going to do any more. I began my good\nactions yesterday.']
qText:
No, Harry, I have done too many dreadful
things in my life. I am not going to do any more. I began my good
actions yesterday.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Where were you yesterday?']
qText: Where were you yesterday?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['In the country, Harry. I was staying at a little inn by myself.']
qText: In the country, Harry. I was staying at a little inn by myself.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['My dear boy,', 'anybody can be good in the
country. There are no temptations there. That is the reason why people
who live out of town are so absolutely uncivilized. Civilization is not
by any means an easy thing to attain to. There are only two ways by
which man can reach it. One is by being cultured, the other by being
corrupt. Country people have no opportunity of being either, so they
stagnate.']
qText:
My dear boy, anybody can be good in the
country. There are no temptations there. That is the reason why people
who live out of town are so absolutely uncivilized. Civilization is not
by any means an easy thing to attain to. There are only two ways by
which man can reach it. One is by being cultured, the other by being
corrupt. Country people have no opportunity of being either, so they
stagnate.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['Culture and corruption,', 'I have known something of
both. It seems terrible to me now that they should ever be found
together. For I have a new ideal, Harry. I am going to alter. I think I
have altered.']
qText:
Culture and corruption, I have known something of
both. It seems terrible to me now that they should ever be found
together. For I have a new ideal, Harry. I am going to alter. I think I
have altered.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You have not yet told me what your good action was. Or did you say you\nhad done more than one?']
qText:
You have not yet told me what your good action was. Or did you say you
had done more than one?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr:
['I can tell you, Harry. It is not a story I could tell to any one else.
I spared somebody. It sounds vain, but you understand what I mean. She
was quite beautiful and wonderfully like Sibyl Vane. I think it was
that which first attracted me to her. You remember Sibyl, don t you?
How long ago that seems! Well, Hetty was not one of our own class, of
course. She was simply a girl in a village. But I really loved her. I
am quite sure that I loved her. All during this wonderful May that we
have been having, I used to run down and see her two or three times a
week. Yesterday she met me in a little orchard. The apple-blossoms kept
tumbling down on her hair, and she was laughing. We were to have gone
away together this morning at dawn. Suddenly I determined to leave her
as flowerlike as I had found her.']
qText:
I can tell you, Harry. It is not a story I could tell to any one else.
I spared somebody. It sounds vain, but you understand what I mean. She
was quite beautiful and wonderfully like Sibyl Vane. I think it was
that which first attracted me to her. You remember Sibyl, don t you?
How long ago that seems! Well, Hetty was not one of our own class, of
course. She was simply a girl in a village. But I really loved her. I
am quite sure that I loved her. All during this wonderful May that we
have been having, I used to run down and see her two or three times a
week. Yesterday she met me in a little orchard. The apple-blossoms kept
tumbling down on her hair, and she was laughing. We were to have gone
away together this morning at dawn. Suddenly I determined to leave her
as flowerlike as I had found her.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Sibyl Vane'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Sibyl Vane'], ['Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr:
['I should think the novelty of the emotion must have given you a thrill
of real pleasure, Dorian,', 'But I can finish
your idyll for you. You gave her good advice and broke her heart. That
was the beginning of your reformation.']
qText:
I should think the novelty of the emotion must have given you a thrill
of real pleasure, Dorian, But I can finish
your idyll for you. You gave her good advice and broke her heart. That
was the beginning of your reformation.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']], [['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr:
['Harry, you are horrible! You mustn t say these dreadful things.
Hetty s heart is not broken. Of course, she cried and all that. But
there is no disgrace upon her. She can live, like Perdita, in her
garden of mint and marigold.']
qText:
Harry, you are horrible! You mustn t say these dreadful things.
Hetty s heart is not broken. Of course, she cried and all that. But
there is no disgrace upon her. She can live, like Perdita, in her
garden of mint and marigold.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['And weep over a faithless Florizel,', 'My dear Dorian, you have the most curiously
boyish moods. Do you think this girl will ever be really content now
with any one of her own rank? I suppose she will be married some day to
a rough carter or a grinning ploughman. Well, the fact of having met
you, and loved you, will teach her to despise her husband, and she will
be wretched. From a moral point of view, I cannot say that I think much
of your great renunciation. Even as a beginning, it is poor. Besides,
how do you know that Hetty isn t floating at the present moment in some
starlit mill-pond, with lovely water-lilies round her, like Ophelia?']
qText:

you, and loved you, will teach her to despise her husband, and she will
be wretched. From a moral point of view, I cannot say that I think much

speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[], [['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr:
['I can t bear this, Harry! You mock at everything, and then suggest the
most serious tragedies. I am sorry I told you now. I don t care what
you say to me. I know I was right in acting as I did. Poor Hetty! As I
rode past the farm this morning, I saw her white face at the window,
like a spray of jasmine. Don t let us talk about it any more, and don t
try to persuade me that the first good action I have done for years,
the first little bit of self-sacrifice I have ever known, is really a
sort of sin. I want to be better. I am going to be better. Tell me
something about yourself. What is going on in town? I have not been to
the club for days.']
qText:

qTextArr: ['The people are still discussing poor Basil s disappearance.']
qText: The people are still discussing poor Basil s disappearance.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I should have thought they had got tired of that by this time,']
qText: I should have thought they had got tired of that by this time,
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['My dear boy, they have only been talking about it for six weeks, and
the British public are really not equal to the mental strain of having
more than one topic every three months. They have been very fortunate
lately, however. They have had my own divorce-case and Alan Campbell s
suicide. Now they have got the mysterious disappearance of an artist.
Scotland Yard still insists that the man in the grey ulster who left
for Paris by the midnight train on the ninth of November was poor
Basil, and the French police declare that Basil never arrived in Paris
at all. I suppose in about a fortnight we shall be told that he has
been seen in San Francisco. It is an odd thing, but every one who
disappears is said to be seen at San Francisco. It must be a delightful
city, and possess all the attractions of the next world.']
qText:
My dear boy, they have only been talking about it for six weeks, and
the British public are really not equal to the mental strain of having

Scotland Yard still insists that the man in the grey ulster who left
for Paris by the midnight train on the ninth of November was poor

city, and possess all the attractions of the next world.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['What do you think has happened to Basil?']
qText: What do you think has happened to Basil?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['I have not the slightest idea. If Basil chooses to hide himself, it is\nno business of mine. If he is dead, I don t want to think about him.\nDeath is the only thing that ever terrifies me. I hate it.']
qText:
I have not the slightest idea. If Basil chooses to hide himself, it is
no business of mine. If he is dead, I don t want to think about him.
Death is the only thing that ever terrifies me. I hate it.
speaker: Lord Henry

qText: Why?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Because,', 'one can survive everything
nowadays except that. Death and vulgarity are the only two facts in the
nineteenth century that one cannot explain away. Let us have our coffee
in the music-room, Dorian. You must play Chopin to me. The man with
whom my wife ran away played Chopin exquisitely. Poor Victoria! I was
very fond of her. The house is rather lonely without her. Of course,
married life is merely a habit, a bad habit. But then one regrets the
loss even of one s worst habits. Perhaps one regrets them the most.
They are such an essential part of one s personality.']
qText:

nowadays except that. Death and vulgarity are the only two facts in the

speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Harry, did it ever\noccur to you that Basil was murdered?']
qText:
Harry, did it ever
occur to you that Basil was murdered?
speaker: Dorian Gray
refExp: he stopped and looking over at Lord Henry said

qTextArr:
['Basil was very popular, and always wore a Waterbury
watch. Why should he have been murdered? He was not clever enough to
have enemies. Of course, he had a wonderful genius for painting. But a
man can paint like Velasquez and yet be as dull as possible. Basil was
really rather dull. He only interested me once, and that was when he
told me, years ago, that he had a wild adoration for you and that you
were the dominant motive of his art.']
qText:
Basil was very popular, and always wore a Waterbury
watch. Why should he have been murdered? He was not clever enough to
have enemies. Of course, he had a wonderful genius for painting. But a
man can paint like Velasquez and yet be as dull as possible. Basil was
really rather dull. He only interested me once, and that was when he
told me, years ago, that he had a wild adoration for you and that you
were the dominant motive of his art.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['I was very fond of Basil,', 'But don t people say that he was murdered?']
qText: I was very fond of Basil, But don t people say that he was murdered?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Oh, some of the papers do. It does not seem to me to be at all
probable. I know there are dreadful places in Paris, but Basil was not
the sort of man to have gone to them. He had no curiosity. It was his
chief defect.']
qText:
Oh, some of the papers do. It does not seem to me to be at all
probable. I know there are dreadful places in Paris, but Basil was not
the sort of man to have gone to them. He had no curiosity. It was his
chief defect.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['What would you say, Harry, if I told you that I had murdered Basil?']
qText: What would you say, Harry, if I told you that I had murdered Basil?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['I would say, my dear fellow, that you were posing for a character that
doesn t suit you. All crime is vulgar, just as all vulgarity is crime.
It is not in you, Dorian, to commit a murder. I am sorry if I hurt your
vanity by saying so, but I assure you it is true. Crime belongs
exclusively to the lower orders. I don t blame them in the smallest
degree. I should fancy that crime was to them what art is to us, simply
a method of procuring extraordinary sensations.']
qText:
I would say, my dear fellow, that you were posing for a character that
doesn t suit you. All crime is vulgar, just as all vulgarity is crime.
It is not in you, Dorian, to commit a murder. I am sorry if I hurt your
vanity by saying so, but I assure you it is true. Crime belongs
exclusively to the lower orders. I don t blame them in the smallest
degree. I should fancy that crime was to them what art is to us, simply
a method of procuring extraordinary sensations.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr: ['A method of procuring sensations? Do you think, then, that a man who\nhas once committed a murder could possibly do the same crime again?\nDon t tell me that.']
qText:
A method of procuring sensations? Do you think, then, that a man who
has once committed a murder could possibly do the same crime again?
Don t tell me that.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Oh! anything becomes a pleasure if one does it too often,', 'That is one of the most important secrets of life. I
should fancy, however, that murder is always a mistake. One should
never do anything that one cannot talk about after dinner. But let us
pass from poor Basil. I wish I could believe that he had come to such a
really romantic end as you suggest, but I can t. I dare say he fell
into the Seine off an omnibus and that the conductor hushed up the
scandal. Yes: I should fancy that was his end. I see him lying now on
his back under those dull-green waters, with the heavy barges floating
over him and long weeds catching in his hair. Do you know, I don t
think he would have done much more good work. During the last ten years
his painting had gone off very much.']
qText:
Oh! anything becomes a pleasure if one does it too often, That is one of the most important secrets of life. I
should fancy, however, that murder is always a mistake. One should
never do anything that one cannot talk about after dinner. But let us
pass from poor Basil. I wish I could believe that he had come to such a

speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[], [['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Basil Hallward'], ['Basil Hallward']]]

qTextArr:
['Yes,', 'his painting had quite gone off. It seemed to me to have
lost something. It had lost an ideal. When you and he ceased to be
great friends, he ceased to be a great artist. What was it separated
you? I suppose he bored you. If so, he never forgave you. It s a habit
bores have. By the way, what has become of that wonderful portrait he
did of you? I don t think I have ever seen it since he finished it. Oh!
I remember your telling me years ago that you had sent it down to
Selby, and that it had got mislaid or stolen on the way. You never got
it back? What a pity! it was really a masterpiece. I remember I wanted
to buy it. I wish I had now. It belonged to Basil s best period. Since
then, his work was that curious mixture of bad painting and good
intentions that always entitles a man to be called a representative
British artist. Did you advertise for it? You should.']
qText:
Yes, his painting had quite gone off. It seemed to me to have
lost something. It had lost an ideal. When you and he ceased to be
great friends, he ceased to be a great artist. What was it separated
you? I suppose he bored you. If so, he never forgave you. It s a habit
bores have. By the way, what has become of that wonderful portrait he

I remember your telling me years ago that you had sent it down to

qTextArr:
['I forget,', 'I suppose I did. But I never really liked it.
I am sorry I sat for it. The memory of the thing is hateful to me. Why
do you talk of it? It used to remind me of those curious lines in some
play Hamlet, I think how do they run?', 'Yes: that is what it was like.']
qText:
I forget, I suppose I did. But I never really liked it.
I am sorry I sat for it. The memory of the thing is hateful to me. Why
do you talk of it? It used to remind me of those curious lines in some
play Hamlet, I think how do they run? Yes: that is what it was like.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['If a man treats life artistically, his brain is\nhis heart,']
qText:
If a man treats life artistically, his brain is
his heart,
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['By the\nway, Dorian,', 'how does the quotation run?']
qText:
By the
way, Dorian, how does the quotation run?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Why do you ask me that, Harry?']
qText: Why do you ask me that, Harry?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['My dear fellow,', 'I asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer.
That is all. I was going through the park last Sunday, and close by the
Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby-looking people
listening to some vulgar street-preacher. As I passed by, I heard the
man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being
rather dramatic. London is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A
wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly
white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful
phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lips it was really very
good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet
that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he
would not have understood me.']
qText:
My dear fellow, I asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer.
That is all. I was going through the park last Sunday, and close by the
Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby-looking people
listening to some vulgar street-preacher. As I passed by, I heard the
man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being
rather dramatic. London is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A
wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly
white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful
phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lips it was really very
good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet
that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he
would not have understood me.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Don t, Harry. The soul is a terrible reality. It can be bought, and\nsold, and bartered away. It can be poisoned, or made perfect. There is\na soul in each one of us. I know it.']
qText:
Don t, Harry. The soul is a terrible reality. It can be bought, and
sold, and bartered away. It can be poisoned, or made perfect. There is
a soul in each one of us. I know it.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Do you feel quite sure of that, Dorian?']
qText: Do you feel quite sure of that, Dorian?
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Quite sure.']
qText: Quite sure.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Ah! then it must be an illusion. The things one feels absolutely
certain about are never true. That is the fatality of faith, and the
lesson of romance. How grave you are! Don t be so serious. What have
you or I to do with the superstitions of our age? No: we have given up
our belief in the soul. Play me something. Play me a nocturne, Dorian,
and, as you play, tell me, in a low voice, how you have kept your
youth. You must have some secret. I am only ten years older than you
are, and I am wrinkled, and worn, and yellow. You are really wonderful,
Dorian. You have never looked more charming than you do to-night. You
remind me of the day I saw you first. You were rather cheeky, very shy,
and absolutely extraordinary. You have changed, of course, but not in
appearance. I wish you would tell me your secret. To get back my youth
I would do anything in the world, except take exercise, get up early,
or be respectable. Youth! There is nothing like it. It s absurd to talk
of the ignorance of youth. The only people to whose opinions I listen
now with any respect are people much younger than myself. They seem in
front of me. Life has revealed to them her latest wonder. As for the
aged, I always contradict the aged. I do it on principle. If you ask
them their opinion on something that happened yesterday, they solemnly
give you the opinions current in 1820, when people wore high stocks,
believed in everything, and knew absolutely nothing. How lovely that
thing you are playing is! I wonder, did Chopin write it at Majorca,
with the sea weeping round the villa and the salt spray dashing against
the panes? It is marvellously romantic. What a blessing it is that
there is one art left to us that is not imitative! Don t stop. I want
music to-night. It seems to me that you are the young Apollo and that I
am Marsyas listening to you. I have sorrows, Dorian, of my own, that
even you know nothing of. The tragedy of old age is not that one is
old, but that one is young. I am amazed sometimes at my own sincerity.
Ah, Dorian, how happy you are! What an exquisite life you have had! You
have drunk deeply of everything. You have crushed the grapes against
your palate. Nothing has been hidden from you. And it has all been to
you no more than the sound of music. It has not marred you. You are
still the same.']
qText:

certain about are never true. That is the fatality of faith, and the
lesson of romance. How grave you are! Don t be so serious. What have
you or I to do with the superstitions of our age? No: we have given up
our belief in the soul. Play me something. Play me a nocturne, Dorian,
and, as you play, tell me, in a low voice, how you have kept your
youth. You must have some secret. I am only ten years older than you
are, and I am wrinkled, and worn, and yellow. You are really wonderful,
Dorian. You have never looked more charming than you do to-night. You
remind me of the day I saw you first. You were rather cheeky, very shy,
and absolutely extraordinary. You have changed, of course, but not in

I would do anything in the world, except take exercise, get up early,
or be respectable. Youth! There is nothing like it. It s absurd to talk
of the ignorance of youth. The only people to whose opinions I listen
now with any respect are people much younger than myself. They seem in

Ah, Dorian, how happy you are! What an exquisite life you have had! You

qTextArr: ['I am not the same, Harry.']
qText: I am not the same, Harry.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['Yes, you are the same. I wonder what the rest of your life will be.
Don t spoil it by renunciations. At present you are a perfect type.
Don t make yourself incomplete. You are quite flawless now. You need
not shake your head: you know you are. Besides, Dorian, don t deceive
yourself. Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a question
of nerves, and fibres, and slowly built-up cells in which thought hides
itself and passion has its dreams. You may fancy yourself safe and
think yourself strong. But a chance tone of colour in a room or a
morning sky, a particular perfume that you had once loved and that
brings subtle memories with it, a line from a forgotten poem that you
had come across again, a cadence from a piece of music that you had
ceased to play I tell you, Dorian, that it is on things like these that
our lives depend. Browning writes about that somewhere; but our own
senses will imagine them for us. There are moments when the odour of
_lilas blanc_ passes suddenly across me, and I have to live the
strangest month of my life over again. I wish I could change places
with you, Dorian. The world has cried out against us both, but it has
always worshipped you. It always will worship you. You are the type of
what the age is searching for, and what it is afraid it has found. I am
so glad that you have never done anything, never carved a statue, or
painted a picture, or produced anything outside of yourself! Life has
been your art. You have set yourself to music. Your days are your
sonnets.']
qText:
Yes, you are the same. I wonder what the rest of your life will be.
Don t spoil it by renunciations. At present you are a perfect type.
Don t make yourself incomplete. You are quite flawless now. You need
not shake your head: you know you are. Besides, Dorian, don t deceive
yourself. Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a question
of nerves, and fibres, and slowly built-up cells in which thought hides
itself and passion has its dreams. You may fancy yourself safe and
think yourself strong. But a chance tone of colour in a room or a
morning sky, a particular perfume that you had once loved and that
brings subtle memories with it, a line from a forgotten poem that you
had come across again, a cadence from a piece of music that you had
ceased to play I tell you, Dorian, that it is on things like these that
our lives depend. Browning writes about that somewhere; but our own
senses will imagine them for us. There are moments when the odour of
_lilas blanc_ passes suddenly across me, and I have to live the
strangest month of my life over again. I wish I could change places
with you, Dorian. The world has cried out against us both, but it has
always worshipped you. It always will worship you. You are the type of
what the age is searching for, and what it is afraid it has found. I am
so glad that you have never done anything, never carved a statue, or
painted a picture, or produced anything outside of yourself! Life has
been your art. You have set yourself to music. Your days are your
sonnets.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Henry'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr:
['Yes, life has been exquisite,', 'but I am not going to
have the same life, Harry. And you must not say these extravagant
things to me. You don t know everything about me. I think that if you
did, even you would turn from me. You laugh. Don t laugh.']
qText:
Yes, life has been exquisite, but I am not going to
have the same life, Harry. And you must not say these extravagant
things to me. You don t know everything about me. I think that if you
did, even you would turn from me. You laugh. Don t laugh.
speaker: Dorian Gray
menEnts: [[], [['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry'], ['Lord Henry']]]

qTextArr:
['Why have you stopped playing, Dorian? Go back and give me the nocturne
over again. Look at that great, honey-coloured moon that hangs in the
dusky air. She is waiting for you to charm her, and if you play she
will come closer to the earth. You won t? Let us go to the club, then.
It has been a charming evening, and we must end it charmingly. There is
some one at White s who wants immensely to know you young Lord Poole,
Bournemouth s eldest son. He has already copied your neckties, and has
begged me to introduce him to you. He is quite delightful and rather
reminds me of you.']
qText:
Why have you stopped playing, Dorian? Go back and give me the nocturne
over again. Look at that great, honey-coloured moon that hangs in the
dusky air. She is waiting for you to charm her, and if you play she
will come closer to the earth. You won t? Let us go to the club, then.
It has been a charming evening, and we must end it charmingly. There is
some one at White s who wants immensely to know you young Lord Poole,
Bournemouth s eldest son. He has already copied your neckties, and has
begged me to introduce him to you. He is quite delightful and rather
reminds me of you.
speaker: Lord Henry
menEnts: [[['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray', 'Lord Henry'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray'], ['Dorian Gray']]]

qTextArr: ['I hope not,', 'But I am tired\nto-night, Harry. I shan t go to the club. It is nearly eleven, and I\nwant to go to bed early.']
qText:
I hope not, But I am tired
to-night, Harry. I shan t go to the club. It is nearly eleven, and I
want to go to bed early.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Do stay. You have never played so well as to-night. There was\nsomething in your touch that was wonderful. It had more expression than\nI had ever heard from it before.']
qText:
Do stay. You have never played so well as to-night. There was
something in your touch that was wonderful. It had more expression than
I had ever heard from it before.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['It is because I am going to be good,', 'I am a\nlittle changed already.']
qText:
It is because I am going to be good, I am a
little changed already.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['You cannot change to me, Dorian,', 'You and I will\nalways be friends.']
qText:
You cannot change to me, Dorian, You and I will
always be friends.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Yet you poisoned me with a book once. I should not forgive that.\nHarry, promise me that you will never lend that book to any one. It\ndoes harm.']
qText:
Yet you poisoned me with a book once. I should not forgive that.
Harry, promise me that you will never lend that book to any one. It
does harm.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr:
['My dear boy, you are really beginning to moralize. You will soon be
going about like the converted, and the revivalist, warning people
against all the sins of which you have grown tired. You are much too
delightful to do that. Besides, it is no use. You and I are what we
are, and will be what we will be. As for being poisoned by a book,
there is no such thing as that. Art has no influence upon action. It
annihilates the desire to act. It is superbly sterile. The books that
the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame.
That is all. But we won t discuss literature. Come round to-morrow. I
am going to ride at eleven. We might go together, and I will take you
to lunch afterwards with Lady Branksome. She is a charming woman, and
wants to consult you about some tapestries she is thinking of buying.
Mind you come. Or shall we lunch with our little duchess? She says she
never sees you now. Perhaps you are tired of Gladys? I thought you
would be. Her clever tongue gets on one s nerves. Well, in any case, be
here at eleven.']
qText:
My dear boy, you are really beginning to moralize. You will soon be
going about like the converted, and the revivalist, warning people
against all the sins of which you have grown tired. You are much too
delightful to do that. Besides, it is no use. You and I are what we
are, and will be what we will be. As for being poisoned by a book,
there is no such thing as that. Art has no influence upon action. It
annihilates the desire to act. It is superbly sterile. The books that
the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame.
That is all. But we won t discuss literature. Come round to-morrow. I
am going to ride at eleven. We might go together, and I will take you
to lunch afterwards with Lady Branksome. She is a charming woman, and
wants to consult you about some tapestries she is thinking of buying.
Mind you come. Or shall we lunch with our little duchess? She says she
never sees you now. Perhaps you are tired of Gladys? I thought you
would be. Her clever tongue gets on one s nerves. Well, in any case, be
here at eleven.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Must I really come, Harry?']
qText: Must I really come, Harry?
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['Certainly. The park is quite lovely now. I don t think there have been\nsuch lilacs since the year I met you.']
qText:
Certainly. The park is quite lovely now. I don t think there have been
such lilacs since the year I met you.
speaker: Lord Henry

qTextArr: ['Very well. I shall be here at eleven,', 'Good night,\nHarry.']
qText:
Very well. I shall be here at eleven, Good night,
Harry.
speaker: Dorian Gray

qTextArr: ['That is Dorian Gray.']
qText: That is Dorian Gray.
speaker: One Young Man
refExp: one of them whisper to the other

qTextArr: ['Whose house is that, Constable?']
qText: Whose house is that, Constable?
speaker: The Elder Of The Two Gentlemen
refExp: asked the elder of the two gentlemen

qText: Mr. Dorian Gray s, sir,
